revision.text:
'''Laurence Dale Richards''' (born 1946) was a key figure in the modern development (since 1981) of [[cybernetics]] as a [[Transdisciplinarity|transdisciplinary]] field of inquiry, often referred to as [[Second-order cybernetics|the new cybernetics]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www2.gwu.edu/~umpleby/recent_papers/2016/2016%20CHK%20Reviving%20ASC%20in%201980s.pdf|title=Reviving the American Society for Cybernetics, 1980-1982|last=Umpleby|first=Stuart|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> He was the first to create [[Interdisciplinarity|interdisciplinary]] masters and doctoral programs in [[engineering management]], with curricula built explicitly on concepts drawn from [[systems theory]] and cybernetics.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://www.odu.edu/content/dam/odu/col-dept/eng/docs/odu-engineering-50.pdf|title=Built From the Ground Up: The First 50 Years of Engineering at Old Dominion University|last=O'Hallarn|first=Brendan|date=|website=|pages=58, 105|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> He served as President for both the [[American Society for Cybernetics]] (1986–88) and the American Society for Engineering Management (1998–99) and was elected an Academician in the [[International Academy for Systems and Cybernetic Sciences]] in 2010.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://asc-cybernetics.org/executive-board/|title=ASC Executive Board - American Society for Cybernetics|website=asc-cybernetics.org|language=en-US|access-date=2017-03-11}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.iascys.org/TheIASCYSacademicians2016yearbook.pdf|title=The IASCYS Academicians 2016 Yearbook|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
== Biography == Richards was born in [[Ann Arbor, Michigan]] and grew up in [[Orono, Maine]]. He received his bachelor's degree in [[electrical engineering]] from the [[University of Maine]] (1968). While serving as a pilot in the [[United States Marine Corps|U.S. Marine Corps]], he earned master's degrees in [[Aeronautics|aeronautical systems]] from the [[University of West Florida]] (1970) and [[Master of Business Administration|business administration]] from [[Mississippi State University]] (1974). He received his [[Doctor of Philosophy|Ph.D.]] in [[operations research]] from the [[Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania|Wharton School]] at the [[University of Pennsylvania]] (1980). Notable accomplishments included: Founding Chair of the Department of Engineering Management at [[Old Dominion University]] (1984–97);<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=http://www.iue.edu/mediarelations/iu-east-interim-leader-richards-makes-career-of-mixing-scholarship-with-administrative-assignments/|title=IU East interim leader Richards makes career of mixing scholarship with administrative assignments {{!}} Media Relations|website=www.iue.edu|language=en-US|access-date=2017-03-13}}</ref> founding Executive Director of the Center for Commercial Space Infrastructure (1992–95), which subsequently morphed into the [[Mid-Atlantic Regional Spaceport|Virginia Space Flight Center]] and commercial spaceport on [[Wallops Island]];<ref name=":1" /><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.odu.edu/content/dam/odu/col-dept/eng/docs/odu-engineering-50.pdf|title=Built From the Ground Up: The First 50 Years of Engineering at Old Dominion University|last=O' Hallarn|first=Brendan|date=|website=|page=68|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.astronautix.com/w/wallopsisland.html|title=Wallops Island|website=www.astronautix.com|access-date=2017-03-11}}</ref> Founding [[Dean (education)|Dean]] of the School of [[Management]] and [[Aviation|Aviation Science]] (1997-2004) at [[Bridgewater State University]];<ref name=":1" /><ref>{{Cite journal|last=|first=|year=Fall 1997|title=Bridgewater State College|url=http://vc.bridgew.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1044&context=br_mag|journal=Bridgewater Magazine|volume=8:1|pages=7|via=}}</ref> inaugural Executive Vice Chancellor for Academic Affairs (2004–15) and Interim [[Chancellor (education)|Chancellor]] (2012–13) at [[Indiana University East]];<ref name=":1" /><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://newsinfo.iu.edu/news-archive/22410.html|title=Larry Richards named interim chancellor at IU East|last=|first=|date=|website=newsinfo.iu.edu|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-03-11}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.iue.edu/people/bio/bio.php?bio=laudrich|title=Faculty Profiles - Faculty & Staff - Indiana University East|website=www.iue.edu|access-date=2017-03-11}}</ref> and, Interim Vice Chancellor & Dean for the [[Indiana University – Purdue University Columbus]] campus (2015–16).<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.iue.edu/chancellor/previous_chancellors.php|title=Previous Chancellors - Office of the Chancellor - Indiana University East|website=www.iue.edu|access-date=2017-03-11}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.iupuc.edu/communications-marketing/News/Item/425/|title=Laurence D. Richards to be appointed interim vice chancellor and dean at IUPUC|website=www.iupuc.edu|access-date=2017-03-13}}</ref> He retired from [[Indiana University]] in 2016 as [[Professor]] [[Emeritus]] of Management and [[Informatics]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.linkedin.com/in/laurencerichards/|title=Laurence Richards|last=|first=|date=|website=LinkedIn|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
== Work == Richards' contributions can be sorted into three areas: (1) his development of constraint theory as an approach to the formulation of [[policy]] and technology [[Strategic thinking|strategy]]; (2) his advancement of the concepts associated with cybernetics as representing a new and powerful way of thinking; and (3) his application of cybernetic ideas to the design of a [[Participatory democracy|participative-dialogic society]].
=== Constraint theory === In his book, ''Constraint Theory'', Richards proposed that, in addressing problems and issues in complex systems involving many participants, desires be treated as constraints rather than as [[goal]]s or objectives (as they are in traditional operations research problem formulation).<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://rowman.com/ISBN/9780819135131/Constraint-Theory-An-Approach-to-Policy-Level-Modelling|title=Constraint-Theory-An-Approach-to-Policy-Level-Modelling}}</ref> In research for [[NASA]], he applied constraint theory to the development of an approach for formulating policy on the selection of new [[Spaceflight|space transportation systems]], given the extreme uncertainty in the technologies that will be available by the time a new system becomes operational.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Richards|first=Laurence D.|date=1996-12-01|title=Analysis of Robustness in the Formulation of Technology Strategy|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1080/10429247.1996.11414915|journal=Engineering Management Journal|volume=8|issue=4|pages=21–32|doi=10.1080/10429247.1996.11414915|issn=1042-9247}}</ref>
=== Cybernetics === Richards recognized a unique potential in the cybernetic version of [[systems thinking]] for addressing complex behavioral and social phenomena. He focused on the ideas of [[hierarchy]], purpose and belief to highlight differences between the process-oriented thinking of cybernetics and, for example, [[Holism|whole systems]] thinking, [[Teleology|teleological or purposeful systems]] thinking, and [[Ideology|ideological systems]] thinking.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Larry|first=Richards,|title=Idea avoidance: reflections on a conference and its language|url=https://www.academia.edu/3708782/Idea_Avoidance_Reflections_on_a_Conference_and_Its_Language|journal=Kybernetes|language=en|volume=42}}</ref> He proposed that: (1) cybernetics be treated as a way of thinking about ways of thinking (of which it – cybernetics – is one), making the way of thinking a choice; and, (2) the [[Cyberneticist|cybernetician]] be treated as a craftsperson in and with time, merging art, science and design.<sup>[4]</sup>
=== Designing (a) society === Since its inception in 1992, Richards was a guest at the School for Designing a Society in [[Urbana, Illinois]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.designingasociety.org/about/organizers/|title=School for Designing a Society :: Organizers and Presenters|website=www.designingasociety.org|language=en|access-date=2017-03-11}}</ref> A premise of the school was that social change can be realized in a transformation from the current to a new society (a change of system), not only in improvements to the current society (changes in a system). Richards saw in the cybernetic concept of [[Conversation theory|conversation]] a particular dialogic with special relevance to processes of design and participation; from this, he created an idea for a participative-dialogic society, a society without violence or at least one where violence is the alternative of last resort.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Richards|first=Larry|title=Beyond Planning: Technological Support for a Desirable Society|url=https://www.academia.edu/3708880/Beyond_Planning_Technological_Support_for_a_Desirable_Society|language=en}}</ref> This idea, he argued, would require a change of thinking.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Richards|first=Larry|title=Difference-making from a Cybernetic Perspective: The Role of Listening and Its Circularities|url=https://www.academia.edu/3708693/Difference-making_from_a_Cybernetic_Perspective_The_Role_of_Listening_and_Its_Circularities|language=en}}</ref>
== Awards and honors == In 2002, Richards was elected a Fellow of the American Society for Engineering Management (#33) and was awarded the Norbert Wiener Medal of the American Society for Cybernetics in 2007.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.asc-cybernetics.org/organization/awards/Richards.pdf|title=The Wiener Gold Medal of the American Society for Cybernetics|last=|first=|date=|website=American Society for Cybernetics|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
== Publications == Richards published over 100 books, monographs, journal/magazine articles, and conference papers. These represent a selection (see also the references): * 2017 From goal-oriented to constraint-oriented design: The cybernetic intersection of design theory and systems theory. ''Leonardo'' 50(1): 36–41 (with Thomas Fischer).<ref>{{Cite journal|last=費道聞|first=Thomas Fischer|last2=Richards|first2=Larry|title=From Goal-oriented to Constraint-oriented Design: The Cybernetic Intersection of Design Theory and Systems Theory (with Thomas Fischer)|url=https://www.academia.edu/8157971/From_Goal-oriented_to_Constraint-oriented_Design_The_Cybernetic_Intersection_of_Design_Theory_and_Systems_Theory_with_Thomas_Fischer_|language=en}}</ref> * 2015 Designing academic conferences in the light of second order cybernetics. ''Constructivist Foundations'' 11(1): 65–73.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Richards|first=Larry|title=Designing Academic Conferences in the Light of Second-Order Cybernetics|url=https://www.academia.edu/31026951/Designing_Academic_Conferences_in_the_Light_of_Second-Order_Cybernetics|language=en}}</ref> * 2014 Education as a subversive activity: A proposal. ''Kybernetes'' 43(9-10): 1392–1398.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Larry|first=Richards,|title=Education as a subversive activity: a proposal|url=https://www.academia.edu/8157996/Education_as_a_subversive_activity_a_proposal|journal=Kybernetes|language=en|volume=43}}</ref> * 2010 The anticommunication imperative. ''Cybernetics and Human Knowing''. 17(1-2):11-24.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Richards|first=Larry|title=The Anticommunication Imperative|url=https://www.academia.edu/3708626/The_Anticommunication_Imperative|language=en}}</ref> * 2009 ''Craft and Constraint, Clocks and Conversation: A Larry Richards Reader 1987 – 2007'', Jason Marrero, Ed.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://pearlheatherforge.wordpress.com/2009/05/20/4/|title=Protected Blog › Log in|website=pearlheatherforge.wordpress.com|language=en|access-date=2017-03-11}}</ref> * 2007 Connecting radical constructivism to social transformation and design. ''Constructivist Foundations'' 2(2-3): 129–135.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Richards|first=Larry|title=Connecting Radical Constructivism to Social Transformation and Design|url=https://www.academia.edu/3708557/Connecting_Radical_Constructivism_to_Social_Transformation_and_Design|language=en}}</ref> * 1996 Propositions on cybernetics and social transformation: Implications of von Foerster's non-trivial machine for knowledge processes. ''Systems Research'' 13(3): 363–369 (with Rochelle K. Young).<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Richards|first=Larry|title=Propositions on Cybernetics and Social Transformation|url=https://www.academia.edu/31026853/Propositions_on_Cybernetics_and_Social_Transformation|language=en}}</ref> * 1985 The systems approach in an information society: A reconsideration. ''Journal of the Operational Research Society'' 36(9): 833–843 (with Shiv K. Gupta).<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/32036809_The_Systems_Approach_in_an_Information_Society_A_Reconsideration|title=The Systems Approach in an Information Society: A Reconsideration*|website=ResearchGate|language=en|access-date=2017-03-11}}</ref> * 1979 Cybernetics and the management science process. ''OMEGA, The International Journal of Management Science'' 8(1): 71–80.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/222800570_Cybernetics_and_the_management_science_process|title=Cybernetics and the management science process|website=ResearchGate|language=en|access-date=2017-03-11}}</ref> * 1979 A language for policy-level modelling. ''Journal of the Operational Research Society'' 30(4): 297–308 (with Shiv K. Gupta).<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/239385964_A_Language_for_Policy-Level_Modelling|title=A Language for Policy-Level Modelling|website=ResearchGate|language=en|access-date=2017-03-11}}</ref>

revision.comment: /* List of Egyptian Ministers of Information (incomplete) */http→https for [[Google Books]] and [[Google News]] using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
{{Infobox Government agency |agency_name = Arab Republic of Egypt
Ministry of Information |nativename = وزارة الاعلام |nativename_a = |nativename_r = |logo =Coat of arms of Egypt (Official).svg |logo_width =150px |logo_caption =[[Emblem of Egypt]] |seal = |seal_width = |seal_caption = |formed = |date1 = |date1_name = |date2 = |date2_name = |preceding1 = |preceding2 = |dissolved = |superseding = |jurisdiction = [[Government of Egypt]] |headquarters = |latd = |latm = |lats = |latNS = |longd = |longm = |longs = |longEW = |employees = |budget = |coordinates = |chief1_name = [[Dorreya Sharaf El-Din]] |chief1_position = Minister of Information |chief2_name = |chief2_position = |chief3_name = |chief3_position = |parent_agency = |child1_agency = |child2_agency = |website = [http://www.ecm.gov.eg Official website] |footnotes = }} {{Politics of Egypt}} The '''Ministry of Information''' is the ministry in charge of [[Mass media|media]] and [[information]] in [[Egypt]]. ==History and profile== The ministry was established in 1982 and it is the successor of the ministry of national guidance.{{cite web|author=Toby Mendel|title=Political and Media Transitions in Egypt|url=http://www1.umn.edu/humanrts/research/Egypt/Internews_Egypt_MediaLawReview_Aug11.pdf|work=Internews|accessdate=24 October 2014|date=August 2011}} Before its foundation the ministry of culture and information also dealt with the duties later held by it. The ministry was abolished in February 2011{{cite news|url=http://thecairopost.com/news/115224/news/breaking-new-government-swear-in|title=BREAKING: New government swears in|date=17 June 2014|accessdate=21 June 2014|work=Cairo Post}}{{cite web|title=Egypt's reinstatement of Information Ministry is a setback|url=http://cpj.org/2011/07/egypts-reinstatement-of-information-ministry-is-ma.php|work=Committee to Protect Journalists|accessdate=3 January 2014|location=New York|date=12 July 2011}} when the new [[Cabinet of Egypt|cabinet]] was created under [[Prime Minister of Egypt|Prime Minister]] [[Essam Sharaf]] after his predecessor [[Ahmed Shafiq]] resigned.{{cite web|url=http://www.cpj.org/2011/07/egypts-reinstatement-of-information-ministry-is-ma.php |title=Egypt's reinstatement of Information Ministry is a setback|work=Committee to Protect Journalists|date=12 July 2011|accessdate=3 July 2014}} It was reestablished in July 2011 and Osama Heikal was appointed minister of information. The headquarters of the ministry is in [[Cairo]]. ==List of Egyptian Ministers of Information (incomplete)== * [[Mansour Hassan]] (1979-1981; as minister of culture and information)(22 December 2012). [http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/61098/Egypt/Politics-/Sadats-last-minister-of-information-dies.aspx Sadat's last minister of information dies], ''Al-Ahram'' * [[Safwat El-Sherif]] (1981-2004)Hammond, Andrew. [https://books.google.com/books?id=m4eodEw7ZvsC&pg=PA79&#v=onepage&q&f=false Pop Culture Arab World!: Media, Arts, and Lifestyle], p. 79 (2005) * [[Anas el-Fiqqi]] (2004-2011) * [[Osama Heikal]] (2011-2012) * [[Salah Abdel Maqsoud]] (2012-2013) * [[Dorreya Sharaf El-Din]] (July 2013-June 2014) ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{portal|Egypt}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Ministry of Information}} [[Category:1982 establishments in Egypt]] [[Category:Ministries established in 1982]] [[Category:Information ministries|Egypt]] [[Category:Government ministries of Egypt|Information]]

revision.comment: Corrected ISO standard reference. ISO 1101/1104 is for Geometrical product specifications related to various GD&T. ISO 16792 is the standard related to digital product definitions and the international counterpart to ASME Y14.41.
revision.text:
'''Model-based enterprise''' (MBE) is a term used in manufacturing, to describe a strategy where an annotated digital three-dimensional (3D) [[3D modeling#Models|model]] of a product serves as the authoritative information source for all activities in that [[Product lifecycle|product's lifecycle]].<ref name=NIST1753>[http://nvlpubs.nist.gov/nistpubs/TechnicalNotes/NIST.TN.1753.pdf "Model Based Enterprise / Technical Data Package Summit Report"]. NIST Technical Note 1753. Retrieved 27 June 2017.</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Gupta|first1=Isha|title=3D Product & Manufacturing Information Implications for Design for Manufacturing|url=https://www.pddnet.com/article/2016/03/3d-product-manufacturing-information-implications-design-manufacturing|website=Product Design and Development|publisher=Advantage Business Media|accessdate=28 June 2017}}</ref>
A key advantage of MBE is that it replaces 2D drawings. In MBE, a single 3D model contains all the information typically found on in an entire set of engineering drawings, including geometry, topology, dimensions, tolerances, materials, finishes, and weld call-outs.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Jackson|first1=Chad|title=The Model Based Enterprise (MBE) Study|url=http://www.lifecycleinsights.com/study/the-model-based-enterprise-mbe-study/|website=Lifecycle Insights|publisher=Lifecycle Insights|accessdate=28 June 2017}}</ref>
MBE was originally championed by the aerospace and defense industries, with the automotive industry following.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Gray|first1=Scott|title=Model Based Enterprise|url=http://www.aiag.org/quality/model-based-enterprise/model-based-enterprise|website=aiag|publisher=Automotive Industry Action Group|accessdate=28 June 2017}}</ref> It has been adopted by many manufacturers around the world, in a wide range of industries. Significant benefits for manufacturers include reduced time to market and savings in production costs from improved tool design and fabrication, fewer overall assembly hours, less rework, streamlined development and better collaboration on engineering changes.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Rouse|first1=Margaret|title=Model-based enterprise|url=http://searchmanufacturingerp.techtarget.com/definition/model-based-enterprise|website=TechTarget|publisher=TechTarget|accessdate=28 June 2017}}</ref>
There are two prerequisites to implementing MBE: The first is the creation of annotated 3D models, known as a [[Model-based definition|Model-based definitions (MBD)]]. This requires the use of a [[Computer aided design|CAD]] system capable of creating precise [[Solid modeling|solid models]], with [[Product and manufacturing information|product and manufacturing information (PMI)]], a form of 3D annotation which may include dimensions, [[Geometric Dimensioning and Tolerancing|GD&T]], notes, surface finish, and material specifications. (The mechanical CAD systems used in aerospace, defense, and automotive industries generally have these capabilities.) The second prerequisite is transforming MBDs into a form where they can be used in downstream lifecycle activities. As a rule, CAD models are stored in proprietary data formats, so they must be translated to a suitable MBD-compatible standard format, such as 3D [[PDF]],<ref>[http://3dpdfconsortium.org/ 3D PDF Consortium]</ref> [[JT (visualization format)|JT]], [[ISO 10303|STEP AP 242]], or [[ANSI]] QIF<ref>[http://qifstandards.org "Quality Information Framework"]</ref>
The core MBE tenet is that models are used to drive all aspects of the product lifecycle and that data is created once and reused by all downstream data consumers. Data reusability requires [[Machine-Readable Documents|computer interpretability]], where an MBD can be processed directly by downstream applications, and associativity of PMI to specific model features within the MBD.<ref name=NIST1753 />
==History==
Historically, engineering and manufacturing activities have relied on hardcopy and/or digital documents (including 2D [[Engineering drawing|drawings]]) to convey engineering data and drive manufacturing processes. These documents required interpretation by skilled practitioners, often leading to ambiguities and errors.<ref>{{cite web |title= Ambiguity in drawing| url=http://www.lboro.ac.uk/microsites/sota/tracey/journal/ambi/images/Willats.pdf|author=John Willats|publisher=TRACEY the online journal of contemporary drawing research |accessdate=2017-06-27}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Tandler|first1=Bill|title=GD&T Workshop: A Top Down View|url=http://www.qualitymag.com/articles/88676-gd-t-workshop-a-top-down-view|website=Quality Magazine|publisher=BNP Media|accessdate=28 June 2017}}</ref>
In the 1980s, improvements in 3D [[solid modeling]] made it possible for CAD systems to precisely represent the shape of most manufactured goods<ref>{{cite web |author=Weisberg, David|title=The Engineering Design Revolution|url=http://www.cadhistory.net/16%20Parametric%20Technology.pdf}}</ref>—however, even enthusiastic adopters of solid modeling technology continued to rely upon 2D drawings (often CAD generated) as the authority (or master) product representation. 3D models, even if geometrically accurate, lacked a method to represent dimensions, tolerances, and other annotative information required to drive manufacturing processes.
In the early-to-middle 2000s, the [[ASME Y14.41-2003| ASME Y14.41-2003 Digital Product Data Definition Practices]] and [[International Organization for Standardization|ISO]] 16792:2006 Technical product documentation -- Digital product definition data practices<ref>{{cite web |title=Technical product documentation -- Digital product definition data practices|url=https://www.iso.org/standard/31065.html|publisher=ISO TC 10 Technical product documentation |accessdate=2018-10-29}}</ref> standards were released, providing support for PMI annotations in 3D CAD models, and introducing the concept of MBD (or, alternatively, digital product definition)<ref>{{cite web |title= Quality Assurance Standard For Digital Product Definition At Boeing Suppliers |url= http://www.boeingsuppliers.com/supplier/D6-51991.pdf|publisher=Boeing D6-51991|accessdate=2017-06-27}}</ref>
The model-based enterprise concept first appeared about 2005. Initially it was construed broadly, referring to the pervasive use of modeling and simulation technologies (of almost any type) throughout an enterprise.<ref>Neal, Richard, [http://www.dtic.mil/ndia/2005/systems/wednesday/neal.pdf "Next Generation Manufacturing Technology Initiative and the Model-Based Enterprise"], NDIA Systems Engineering Conference, San Diego, California October 26, 2005. Retrieved on 27 June 2017.</ref> In the late 2000s, An active community advocating development of MBE grew, based on the collaborative efforts of the Office of the [[Secretary of Defense]], [[Army Research Laboratory]], [[ARDEC|Armament Research Development Engineering Center (ARDEC)]], [http://www.armymantech.com/ Army ManTech], [[BAE Systems]], [[NIST]], and the NIST Manufacturing Extension Partnership (MEP).<ref>{{cite web|last1=Leonarf|first1=Scott|title=Advanced Manufacturing Enterprise Strategic Baseline|url=https://www.dodmantech.com/JDMTP/Files/AME_Strategic_Baseline_03_Nov_11.pdf|website=DoD ManTech|publisher=US Department of Defense|accessdate=28 June 2017}}</ref> The "MBE Team" included industry participants such as [[General Dynamics]], [[Pratt & Whitney]] [[Rocketdyne]], Elysium, [[Adobe Systems|Adobe]], EOS, ITI TranscenData, Vistagy, [[PTC (software company)|PTC]], [[Dassault Systemes]] Delmia, [[Boeing]], and [[BAE Systems]].<ref name=osd>{{cite web|last1=Whittenburg|first1=Mitzi|title=Model Based Enterprise and its Impact on Small Businesses|url=http://www.acq.osd.mil/osbp/councils/marc/resources/201103-model-based-enterprise.pdf|website=osd.mil|publisher=Office of the Secretary of Defense|accessdate=28 June 2017}}</ref>
Over time, based on community feedback, MBE became more narrowly construed, referring to the use of MBD data to drive product lifecycle activities.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Frechette|first1=S|title=Model Based Enterprise for Manufacturing|url=http://ws680.nist.gov/publication/get_pdf.cfm?pub_id=908343|website=NIST|publisher=National Institute of Standards and Technology|accessdate=28 June 2017}}</ref><ref name=NIST1753 /> In 2011, the MBE Team published these definitions:
* MBD: A 3D annotated model and its associated data elements that fully define the product definition in a manner that can be used effectively by all downstream customers in place of a traditional drawing. * MBE: A fully integrated and collaborative environment founded on 3D product definition detail and shared across the enterprise; to enable rapid, seamless, and affordable deployment of products from concept to disposal<ref name=osd />
By 2015, with improvements to ASME Y14.41 and ISO 16792, and the development of open [[CAD data exchange]] standards capable of adequately representing PMI, MBE started to become more widely adopted by manufacturers.
== References == <!-- Inline citations added to your article will automatically display here. See https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WP:REFB for instructions on how to add citations. --> {{reflist}}
[[Category:Engineering concepts]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox scientist | name = Natalya Bailey | image = | birth_name = Natalya Anna Brikner | birth_date = 1987 | birth_place = Oregon, USA | fields = [[Aerospace engineer]] | workplaces = Accion Systems, Inc. | alma_mater = [[San Diego State University]]
[[Duke University]]
[[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]] | thesis_title = On the Identification and Mitigation of Life-limiting Mechanisms of Ionic Liquid Ion Sources Envisaged for Propulsion of Microspacecraft | thesis_url = http://ssl.mit.edu/files/website/theses/PhD-2014-BriknerNatalya.pdf | thesis_year = 2015 | academic_advisors = [[Paulo Lozano]] | known_for = Accion Systems Co-Founder & CEO }} '''Natalya Bailey''' is an [[aerospace engineer]] and co-founder and Chief Executive Officer of the space start-up Accion Systems Inc. == Education == Bailey received her Bachelor's degree in [[aerospace engineering]] in 2008 from [[San Diego State University]]. She then completed her Master's degree in [[mechanical engineering]] at [[Duke University]] in 2011 before attending [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]], where she received her Ph.D. in [[aeronautics]] and [[astronautics]] in 2015.{{Cite web|url=https://www.bizjournals.com/boston/news/2017/02/16/women-to-watch-natalya-bailey-founder-and-ceo-of.html|title=Women to Watch: Natalya Bailey — Founder and CEO of Accion Systems Inc.|last=|first=|date=|website=www.bizjournals.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-08-10}} At MIT, she conducted her doctoral research in the Space Propulsion Laboratory, directed by [[Paulo Lozano]].{{Cite journal|date=2015|others=Paulo C. Lozano., Massachusetts Institute of Technology. Department of Aeronautics and Astronautics., Massachusetts Institute of Technology. Department of Aeronautics and Astronautics.|title=On the identification and mitigation of life-limiting mechanisms of ionic liquid ion sources envisaged for propulsion of microspacecraft|url=https://dspace.mit.edu/handle/1721.1/97350}} == Research & Accion Systems == Bailey's graduate research became the foundation for Accion Systems, which she co-founded in 2014 with fellow MIT graduate Louis Perna.{{Cite news|url=https://www.technologyreview.com/s/602282/how-natalya-brikner-became-a-rocket-scientist-and-ceo-before-30/|title=How one woman became a rocket scientist, inventor, and CEO before her 30th birthday|last=Brewster|first=Signe|work=MIT Technology Review|access-date=2018-08-10|language=en}} During her doctoral work, she helped invent a working prototype for a small engine for small satellites using liquid ion propulsion—or electrospray propulsion—technology.{{Citation|last=|first=|title=Method and apparatus for a porous electrospray emitter|url=https://patents.google.com/patent/US8791411B2/en|volume=|pages=|publication-date=2013-03-15|access-date=2018-08-10}}{{Cite journal|last=Brikner|first=Natalya|last2=Lozano|first2=Paulo C.|date=2012-11-05|title=The role of upstream distal electrodes in mitigating electrochemical degradation of ionic liquid ion sources|url=https://aip.scitation.org/doi/abs/10.1063/1.4766293|journal=Applied Physics Letters|language=en|volume=101|issue=19|pages=193504|doi=10.1063/1.4766293|issn=0003-6951|bibcode=2012ApPhL.101s3504B}} The prototype, which is about the same size as a deck of cards, was the first of its kind and will allow small satellites to remain on orbit for longer periods of time.{{Cite news|url=https://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20180627005252/en/Accion-Systems%E2%80%99-Natalya-Bailey-Named-MIT-Technology|title=Accion Systems’ Natalya Bailey Named To MIT Technology Review’s 2018 Innovators Under 35 List|access-date=2018-08-10|language=en}} Small satellites are better suited to avoiding collisions with debris and can reach further orbits to more distant planets and asteroids, enabling further space exploration. The technology can also be scaled up to provide propulsion for larger spacecrafts. Accion is currently working to commercialize the technology, which has the benefit of being more cost effective to manufacture and has significant safety advantages over more traditional engine systems because the engine doesn't require toxic propellants or pressurized tanks to work.{{Cite news|url=https://www.technologyreview.com/lists/innovators-under-35/2018/entrepreneur/natalya-bailey/|title=Natalya Bailey helped create a system to propel tiny satellites via electrical energy.|work=MIT Technology Review|access-date=2018-08-10|language=en}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/features/2018-07-26/ion-engine-startup-wants-to-change-the-economics-of-earth-orbit|title=Ion Engine Startup Wants to Change the Economics of Earth Orbit|work=Bloomberg.com|access-date=2018-08-10}} Since its founding, Accion Systems has been awarded a $3 million Rapid Innovation Fund contract through the [[United States Department of Defense]] and has raised $7.5 million in [[Series A funding]] led by [[Shasta Ventures]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.satellitetoday.com/innovation/2015/06/18/accion-systems-awarded-3-million-dod-contract/|title=Accion Systems Awarded $3 Million DOD Contract - Via Satellite -|date=2015-06-18|work=Via Satellite|access-date=2018-08-10|language=en-US}}{{Cite news|url=https://techcrunch.com/2016/05/12/accion-systems-raises-series-a/|title=Accion Systems raises $7.5 million in Series A to accelerate production of miniature space thrusters|work=TechCrunch|access-date=2018-08-10|language=en-US}} In October 2018, Boeing announced to invest in Accion Systems Inc. The project will lead the development of satellite propulsion for low and medium Earth orbit and deep space.{{Cite news|url=https://spacenews.com/boeing-investing-in-satellite-propulsion-startup/|title=Boeing investing in satellite propulsion startup - SpaceNews.com|date=2018-10-10|work=SpaceNews.com|access-date=2018-10-17|language=en-US}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.bizjournals.com/boston/news/2018/10/10/aerospace-startup-lands-funding-led-by-boeing.html|title=https://www.bizjournals.com/boston/news/2018/10/10/aerospace-startup-lands-funding-led-by-boeing.html|website=www.bizjournals.com|access-date=2018-10-17}} == Awards & Honors == * 35 Innovators Under 35, [[MIT Technology Review]], 2018{{Cite news|url=https://www.technologyreview.com/lists/innovators-under-35/2018/|title=Innovators Under 35 {{!}} 2018|work=MIT Technology Review|access-date=2018-08-10|language=en}} * 30 Under 30, [[Inc. (magazine)|''Inc'']], 2017{{Cite news|url=https://www.inc.com/david-whitford/30-under-30-2017-accion-systems.html|title=How This Founder's Alien Obsession Launched Her Company--Into Outer Space|date=2017-04-25|work=Inc.com|access-date=2018-08-10}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.inc.com/will-yakowicz/inc-uncensored-podcast-episode-115.html|title=How a First Date Led to a Prototype, a Startup, and a Marriage|date=2017-05-05|work=Inc.com|access-date=2018-08-10}} *Women to Watch, [[Boston Business Journal]], 2017 *[[Forbes 30 Under 30]], 2016{{Cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/pictures/ehde45ememm/louis-perna-28-natalya/#37e3b12b3fe7|title=Louis Perna, 28, Natalya Brikner, 29|last=|first=|date=|website=Forbes|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-08-10}} == References == {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Bailey, Natalya}} [[Category:1987 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Women in science and technology]] [[Category:Aerospace engineers]] [[Category:American businesspeople]] [[Category:Chief executive officers]] [[Category:Massachusetts Institute of Technology alumni]] [[Category:San Diego State University alumni]] [[Category:Duke University alumni]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2013}} {{Infobox military person |name=Oliver Haywood |birth_date= {{birth date|1911|11|29|df=yes}} |death_date= {{death date and age|2002|05|25|1911|11|29|df=yes}} |birth_place=[[Highland Mills, New York]] |death_place=[[Vero Beach, Florida]] |placeofburial= |placeofburial_label= |image= |caption= |allegiance={{flag|United States of America}} |branch=[[File:US Department of the Army seal.png|25px]] [[United States Army]] (1936–1947)
[[File:Seal of the US Air Force.svg|25px]] [[United States Air Force]] (1947–1967) |serviceyears=1936–1967 |rank=[[File:US-O7 insignia.svg|15px]] [[Brigadier General (United States)|Brigadier General]] |commands=[[130th Engineer Battalion (United States)|130th Engineer Battalion]] |battles=[[World War II]] |awards=[[Legion of Merit]] (2) |laterwork=President and CEO, Chairman of Huyck Corporation }} '''Oliver Garfield Haywood, Jr.,''' (29 November 1911 – 25 May 2002) was a [[United States Army]] officer during [[World War II]] who served with the [[Manhattan Project]]. He transferred to the [[United States Air Force]] in 1947. After retiring from active duty in 1953, he became President and chief executive officer, and later chairman, of Huyck Corporation. ==Early life and career== Oliver Garfield Haywood, Jr., was born in [[Highland Mills, New York]] on 29 November 1911. He entered the [[United States Military Academy]] at [[West Point]] on 1 July 1932, and graduated top of the class of 1936 on 12 June 1936. His class included [[Bruce Palmer, Jr.]], who graduated sixth. Haywood was commissioned as a [[second lieutenant]] in the [[United States Army Corps of Engineers]], and was posted to [[Vicksburg, Mississippi]], as executive officer of the [[Waterways Experiment Station]]. In June 1937, went to [[Conchas Dam]] in New Mexico as assistant to the District Engineer,{{cite book | title = Biographical Register of the Officers and Graduates of the US Military Academy at West Point New York Since Its Establishment in 1802: Supplement Volume VIII 1930–1940 | last = Cullum | first = George W. | author-link = George Washington Cullum | publisher = R. R. Donnelly and Sons, The Lakeside Press | location = Chicago, Illinois | year = 1940 | url=http://digital-library.usma.edu/cdm/compoundobject/collection/p16919coll3/id/19424/rec/9 | accessdate=6 October 2015 | page = 1132 | df = dmy-all }} [[Captain (United States O-3)|Captain]] Hans Kramer. The dam was under construction at the time, and was a major undertaking.{{cite web |author = Schelburg, John D. |title = Conchas Dam |publisher = New Mexico Office of the State Historian |url = http://www.newmexicohistory.org/filedetails.php?fileID=9944 |accessdate = 27 July 2013 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20120320144932/http://www.newmexicohistory.org/filedetails.php?fileID=9944 |archivedate = 20 March 2012 |df = dmy-all }} On 25 September 1938, Haywood entered [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]] (MIT) as a student officer. While there he was promoted to [[first lieutenant]] on 12 June 1939. On 25 September 1939, he also became a graduate student at [[Harvard University]]'s [[Harvard School of Engineering and Applied Sciences|Graduate School of Engineering]]. He received his [[Master of Science]] (MS) degree from Harvard on 20 June 1940, and his [[Doctor of Science]] (DSc) degree from MIT on 15 August. He was promoted to captain on 15 September. ==World War II== Haywood assumed command of Company C, [[27th Engineer Battalion (United States)|27th Engineer Battalion]] in [[Puerto Rico]] on 13 September 1940. He then commanded the 130th Engineer Battalion there from 16 April 1941 until 31 December 1941. On 1 January 1942, he became executive officer of the 78th Engineers there. He was promoted to major in the wartime [[Army of the United States]] on 1 February 1942. He attended the [[United States Army Command and General Staff College|Command and General Staff College]] at [[Fort Leavenworth, Kansas]], from November 1942 to February 1943, before returning to Puerto Rico for duty on the staff of the Antilles Department. He was promoted to [[lieutenant colonel]] on 14 February 1943.{{cite book |title = Biographical Register of the Officers and Graduates of the US Military Academy at West Point New York since its Establishment in 1802: Supplement Volume IX 1940–1950 |last = Cullum |first = George W. |author-link = George Washington Cullum |publisher = R. R. Donnelly and Sons, The Lakeside Press |location = Chicago, Illinois |year = 1950 |url = http://digital-library.usma.edu/cdm/compoundobject/collection/p16919coll3/id/22314/rec/10 |accessdate = 13 February 2010 |pages = 859–860 |df = dmy-all }} In October 1943, Haywood was assigned to the G-1 (Personnel) Division of the [[War Department General Staff]] in Washington, D.C. For his services in this role, he was promoted to [[colonel]] on 28 September 1944, and was awarded the [[Legion of Merit]]. On 5 August 1945, he became Assistant Chief of Staff (G-1) at headquarters, [[European Theater of Operations]] (ETO). For his services during the [[demobilization]], he was awarded a second Legion of Merit. ==After the war== [[File:Los Alamos colloquium.jpg|thumb|left|300px|Haywood (left) at a 1946 [[Los Alamos National Laboratory|Los Alamos]] colloquium on the [[Hydrogen bomb]]]] Haywood was transferred to the headquarters of the [[Manhattan Project]] on 12 April 1946. He was one of a number West Point graduates from the top ten percent of their classes who were transferred to the Manhattan Project at this time by the [[Secretary of War]], [[Robert P. Patterson]], at the request of the Manhattan Project's commander, [[Major General (United States)|Major General]] [[Leslie R. Groves, Jr.]], and over the objection of senior Army leaders. Their job was to replace reservists who had worked for the Project during the war and now were eligible for separation from the Army.{{sfn|Groves|1962|pp=373–376}} Haywood participated in [[Operation Crossroads|Operation ''Crossroads'']], observing the [[nuclear test]]s at [[Bikini Atoll]].{{cite web |url=http://www.mphpa.org/classic/VET_ARCHIVES/MPVA_16.htm#haywood |publisher=Manhattan Project veterans archives |title=Haywood, Oliver G. |accessdate=27 July 2013 |dead-url=usurped |archive-date=2013-05-01 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130501174940/http://www.mphpa.org/classic/VET_ARCHIVES/MPVA_16.htm#haywood |df=dmy-all}} Groves hoped that a new, permanent agency would soon be created to take over the responsibilities of the wartime Manhattan Project, but passage of the [[Atomic Energy Act of 1946]] through Congress took much longer than expected, and involved considerable debate about the proper role of the military with respect to the development, production and control of nuclear weapons.{{sfn|Groves|1962|pp=389–391}} The act that was finally signed by President [[Harry S. Truman]] on 1 August 1946 created a civilian agency, the [[United States Atomic Energy Commission|Atomic Energy Commission]] (AEC), to take over the functions and assets of the Manhattan Project, but the AEC did not assume its role until 1 January 1947.{{sfn|Groves|1962|pp=394–395}} At this point, Haywood was seconded to the AEC's Directorate of Research. Although he had been a colonel in the Army of the United States, Haywood only held the substantive rank of captain in the Army Corps of Engineers. His Army of the United States rank was terminated on 30 June 1947, and he returned to duty with the War Department General Staff as a captain on 1 July 1947. Haywood elected to transfer to the newly created [[United States Air Force]] on 10 December 1947. He became a lieutenant colonel on 1 July 1948, and was assigned to the Air Plans Division on 29 August 1948,. where he was involved in drawing up nuclear war plans. From July 1949 to May 1950 he attended the [[Air War College]] at [[Maxwell Air Force Base]], Alabama. Haywood was seconded to the [[Los Alamos National Laboratory]] in New Mexico from February 1950 to October 1951, at a time when the first [[thermonuclear weapon]]s were being developed. [[Edward Teller]] once remarked that "Colonel Haywood is the only military man I would work for."{{cite web |url=http://www.mphpa.org/classic/VET_ARCHIVES/More/16-04_haywood.htm |publisher=Manhattan Project veterans archives |title=Haywood, Oliver G. – More Info |accessdate=27 July 2013 |dead-url=usurped |archive-date=2013-05-21 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130521004655/http://www.mphpa.org/classic/VET_ARCHIVES/More/16-04_haywood.htm |df=dmy-all}} Haywood then served at the chief of the Air Force Office of Scientific Research, and was vice commander of the [[Atlantic Missile Range]] until his retirement from active duty in 1953. He remained with the [[Air Force Reserve]], retiring with the rank of [[brigadier general]] in 1967.{{cite web |url=http://www.westpointaog.org/NetCommunity/Document.Doc?id=1226 |title=Brigadier General Oliver Garfield Haywood Class of 1936 |publisher=West Point Alumni Association |accessdate=27 July 2013}} ==Later life== After leaving the Air Force, Haywood became the President and chief executive officer, and later the chairman of the board of Huyck Corporation in [[Stamford, Connecticut]]. He was also chairman and acting president of the [[Hudson Institute]] in Indianapolis.{{cite journal |journal=Harvard magazine |date=September–October 2002 |url=http://www.zoominfo.com/CachedPage/?archive_id=0&page_id=388550142&page_url=//www.harvard-magazine.com/on-line/0902177.html&page_last_updated=2003-02-01T12:00:19&firstName=O.G.&lastName=Haywood |title=Obituaries |issn=0095-2427 |accessdate=27 July 2013 }} Haywood died in [[Vero Beach, Florida]], on 25 May 2002. He was survived by his daughters, Barbara and Betty, and sons, Richard and Robert. His wife, Helen, had predeceased him. ==Notes== {{Portal|Biography|World War II|United States Air Force|Nuclear technology}} {{reflist|30em}} ==References== * {{cite book |last=Groves|first=Leslie |authorlink=Leslie Groves |title=Now it Can be Told: The Story of the Manhattan Project |location=New York |publisher=Harper & Row |year=1962 |isbn=0-306-70738-1 |oclc=537684 |ref=harv }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Haywood, Oliver}} [[Category:1911 births]] [[Category:2002 deaths]] [[Category:Air War College alumni]] [[Category:American army personnel of World War II]] [[Category:Harvard School of Engineering and Applied Sciences alumni]] [[Category:Massachusetts Institute of Technology alumni]] [[Category:Military personnel from New York City]] [[Category:Recipients of the Legion of Merit]] [[Category:Manhattan Project people]] [[Category:United States Air Force generals]] [[Category:United States Military Academy alumni]] [[Category:People from Highland Falls, New York]]

[[Digital distribution]] | parent = [[EVS Broadcast Equipment]] | divisions = | subsid = | homepage = [http://www.opencubetech.com/] | footnotes = | intl = }} '''Open Cube Solutions, LLC''' is a [[United States|French]] [[company]] headquartered in [[Clifton, New Jersey|Toulouse]], member of the gJ roup [[EVS Broadcast Equipment]]. Established on April, 2003, Open Cube Technologies develops, manufactures, licenses, and supports a wide range of [[software]] and [[computer hardware|hardware]] for the [[broadcast]] and [[film|cinema]] industries. Active in [[computing]], [[broadcast]] and [[video]], OpenCube Technologies provides [[MXF]]-format solutions (MXF server, MXF player, MXF converter, MXF Toolkit) and media content management services. OpenCube has been acquired by [[EVS Broadcast Equipment]] in 2010 [http://www.opencubetech.com/userdoc/opencube_joins_evs.pdf OpenCube joins EVS] and is now part of the EVS Media division. The company has been awarded in 2008 at the SATIS (''Salon international de l'audiovisuel'' of [[Paris]]) for its product ''P2SoftHD''.[http://fr.opencubetech.com/page70/ SATIS award] Its customers are [[Airbus]],[http://fr.opencubetech.com/page79/ OpenCube & Airbus] [[MTV]][http://fr.opencubetech.com/page75/ OpenCube & MTV] or [[20th Century Fox]].[http://fr.opencubetech.com/userdoc/opencube_20th_cent_fox_2010.pdf OpenCube & 20th Century Fox] == See also == * [[MXF]] * [[EVS Broadcast Equipment]] == External links == * [http://www.evs.com/mxfserver OpenCube MXF server on EVS' website] == References == {{Reflist}} [[Category:Computer hardware companies]] [[Category:Electronics companies of France]] [[Category:Software companies of France]] [[Category:Cloud computing providers]] [[Category:Film and video technology]] [[Category:Companies based in Toulouse]] [[Category:Computer companies established in 2003]] [[Category:French companies established in 2003]] {{-}} {{video-tech-stub}}

{{Use British English Oxford spelling|date=December 2011}} In [[industrial design]], '''preferred numbers''' (also called '''preferred values''' or '''preferred series''') are standard guidelines for choosing exact product dimensions within a given set of constraints. Product developers must choose numerous lengths, distances, diameters, volumes, and other characteristic [[quantities]]. While all of these choices are constrained by considerations of functionality, usability, compatibility, safety or cost, there usually remains considerable leeway in the ''exact'' choice for many dimensions.
Preferred numbers serve two purposes: # Using them increases the probability of compatibility between objects designed at different times by different people. In other words, it is one tactic among many in [[standardization]], whether within a company or within an industry, and it is usually desirable in industrial contexts (unless the goal is [[vendor lock-in]] or [[planned obsolescence]]) # They are chosen such that when a product is manufactured in many different sizes, these will end up roughly equally spaced on a [[logarithmic scale]]. They therefore help to minimize the number of different sizes that need to be manufactured or kept in stock.
Preferred numbers represent preferences of simple numbers (such as 1, 2, and 5) multiplied by the powers of a convenient basis, usually 10.<ref name="GOVPUB-C13"/>
==Renard numbers== {{Main|Renard series}}
In 1870 [[Charles Renard]] proposed a set of preferred numbers.<ref name="Sizes_2014"/> His system was adopted in 1952 as international standard [[ISO 3]].<ref name="ISO_3_1973"/> Renard's system divides the interval from 1 to 10 into 5, 10, 20, or 40 steps, leading to the R5, R10, R20 and R40 scales, respectively. The factor between two consecutive numbers in a [[Renard series]] is approximately constant (before rounding), namely the 5th, 10th, 20th, or 40th root of 10 (approximately 1.58, 1.26, 1.12, and 1.06, respectively), which leads to a [[geometric sequence]]. This way, the maximum [[relative error]] is minimized if an arbitrary number is replaced by the nearest Renard number multiplied by the appropriate power of 10.
=={{anchor|1-2-5 series}} 1–2–5 series== In applications for which the R5 series provides a too fine graduation, the 1–2–5 series is sometimes used as a cruder alternative. It is effectively an R3 series rounded to one significant digit:
:… 0.1 0.2 0.5 1 2 5 10 20 50 100 200 500 1000 …
This series covers a [[decade (log scale)|decade]] (1:10 ratio) in three steps. Adjacent values differ by factors 2 or 2.5. Unlike the Renard series, the 1–2–5 series has not been formally adopted as an [[international standard]]. However, the Renard series R10 can be used to extend the 1–2–5 series to a finer graduation.
This series is used to define the scales for graphs and for instruments that display in a two-dimensional form with a graticule, such as [[oscilloscope#Graticule|oscilloscopes]].
The [[denomination (currency)|denominations]] of most modern [[Currency|currencies]], notably the [[euro]] and [[British pound]], follow a 1–2–5 series. The United States and Canada follow the approximate 1–2–5 series 1, 5, 10, 25, 50, 100 (cents), $1, $2, $5, $10, $20, $50, $100. The {{1/4}}–{{1/2}}–1 series (… 0.1 0.25 0.5 1 2.5 5 10 …) is also used by currencies derived from the former [[Dutch gulden]] ([[Aruban florin]], [[Netherlands Antillean gulden]], [[Surinamese dollar]]), some Middle Eastern currencies ([[Iraqi dinar|Iraqi]] and [[Jordanian dinar|Jordanian]] dinars, [[Lebanese pound]], [[Syrian pound]]), and the [[Seychellois rupee]]. However, newer notes introduced in Lebanon and Syria due to inflation follow the standard 1–2–5 series instead.
==Convenient numbers== {{Main|Convenient numbers}}
In the 1970s the [[National Bureau of Standards]] (NBS) defined a set of convenient numbers to ease [[metrication in the United States]]. This system of metric values was described as [[#1–2–5 series|1–2–5 series]] in reverse, with assigned preferences for those numbers which are multiples of 5, 2, and 1 (plus their powers of 10), excluding linear dimensions above 100 mm.<ref name="GOVPUB-C13"/>
==E-series== {{Main|E-series of preferred numbers}} The E-series is another system of preferred numbers. It consists of the [[E3 series (preferred numbers)|E3]], [[E6 series (preferred numbers)|E6]], [[E12 series (preferred numbers)|E12]], [[E24 series (preferred numbers)|E24]], [[E48 series (preferred numbers)|E48]], [[E96 series (preferred numbers)|E96]] and [[E192 series (preferred numbers)|E192]] series. Based on some of the existing manufacturing conventions, the [[International Electrotechnical Commission]] (IEC) began work on a new international standard in 1948.<ref name="IEC_60063_1952"/> The first version of this [[IEC 63]] (renamed into [[IEC 60063]] in 2007) was released in 1952.<ref name="IEC_60063_1952"/>
It works similarly to the Renard series, except that it subdivides the interval from 1 to 10 into 3, 6, 12, 24, 48, 96 or 192 steps. These subdivisions ensure that when some arbitrary value is replaced with the nearest preferred number, the maximum relative error will be on the order of 40%, 20%, 10%, 5%, etc.
Use of the E-series is mostly restricted to [[electronics|electronic parts]] like resistors, capacitors, inductors and Zener diodes. Commonly produced dimensions for other types of electrical components are either chosen from the Renard series instead or are defined in relevant product standards (for example [[IEC 60228|wires]]).
== Audio frequencies == ISO 266, Acoustics—Preferred frequencies, defines two different series of audio frequencies for use in acoustical measurements. Both series are referred to the standard reference frequency of 1000 Hz, and use the R10 [[Renard series]] from ISO 3, with one using powers of 10, and the other related to the definition of the octave as the frequency ratio 1:2.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://webshop.ds.dk/Files/Files/Products/18315_attachPV.pdf|title=ISO 266: Acoustics—Preferred frequencies|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
For example, a set of nominal center frequencies for use in audio tests and audio test equipment is: {| class="wikitable" |+Frequencies to be used in one-third octave analyzers in the audible range<ref>{{Cite book|title=Software-Based Acoustical Measurements|last=Miyara|first=Federico|publisher=Springer Nature|year=2017|isbn=978-3-319-55870-7|location=|pages=21}}</ref> !Nominal Center Frequency (Hz) |- |20 |- |25 |- |31.5 |- |40 |- |50 |- |63 |- |80 |- |100 |- |125 |- |160 |- |200 |- |250 |- |315 |- |400 |- |500 |- |630 |- |800 |- |1000 |- |1250 |- |1600 |- |2000 |- |2500 |- |3150 |- |4000 |- |5000 |- |6300 |- |8000 |- |10000 |- |12500 |- |16000 |- |20000 |}
== Computer engineering == When dimensioning computer components, the powers of two are frequently used as preferred numbers:
1 2 4 8 16 32 64 128 256 512 1024 …
Where a finer grading is needed, additional preferred numbers are obtained by multiplying a power of two with a small odd integer:
1 2 4 8 16 32 64 128 256 512 1024 … (×3) 3 6 12 24 48 96 192 384 768 1536 … (×5) 5 10 20 40 80 160 320 640 1280 … (×7) 7 14 28 56 112 224 448 896 1792 …
{| class="wikitable" align="right" |+ Preferred aspect ratios ! !! 16: !! 15: !! 12: <!--| (2²)² || 3 × 5 || 2² × 3--> |- ! :8 <!--|| 2³--> | 2:1 || || 3:2 |- ! :9<!--|| 3²--> |16:9 || 5:3 || 4:3 |- ! :10<!--|| 2 × 5--> | 8:5 || 3:2 || <!--not preferred--> |- ! :12<!--|| 2² × 3--> | 4:3 || 5:4 || 1:1 |} In [[computer graphics]], widths and heights of [[Raster graphics|raster images]] are preferred to be multiples of 16, as many compression algorithms ([[JPEG]], [[MPEG]]) divide ''color'' images into square blocks of that size. Black-and-white JPEG images are divided into 8×8 blocks. Screen resolutions often follow the same principle. Preferred [[aspect ratio]]s have also an important influence here, e.g., 2:1, 3:2, 4:3, 5:3,
== Paper documents, envelopes, and drawing pens == {{Main|Paper size}} Standard metric paper sizes use the [[square root]] of two ({{sqrt|2}}) as factors between neighbouring dimensions rounded to the nearest mm ([[Georg Christoph Lichtenberg|Lichtenberg]] series, [[ISO 216]]). An A4 sheet for example has an aspect ratio very close to {{sqrt|2}} and an area very close to 1/16 square metre. An A5 is almost exactly half an A4, and has the same aspect ratio. The {{sqrt|2}} factor also appears between the standard pen thicknesses for technical drawings (0.13, 0.18, 0.25, 0.35, 0.50, 0.70, 1.00, 1.40, and 2.00 mm). This way, the right pen size is available to continue a drawing that has been magnified to a different standard paper size.
== Photography == In photography, aperture, exposure, and film speed generally follow powers of 2:
The aperture size controls how much light enters the camera. It is measured in [[F-number|f-stop]]s: {{f/|1.4}}, {{f/|2}}, {{f/|2.8}}, {{f/|4}}, etc. Full f-stops are a [[square root of 2]] apart. Digital cameras often subdivide these into thirds, so each f-stop is a sixth root of 2, rounded to two significant digits: 1.0, 1.1, 1.2, 1.4, 1.6, 1.8, 2.0, 2.2, 2.5, 2.8, 3.2, 3.5, 4.0, etc.
The [[film speed]] is a measure of the film's sensitivity to light. It is expressed as ISO values such as "ISO 100". Measured film speeds are rounded to the nearest preferred number from a modified Renard series including 100, 125, 160, 200, 250, 320, 400, 500, 640, 800… This is the same as the R10′ rounded [[Renard series]], except for the use of 6.4 instead of 6.3, and for having more aggressive rounding below ISO 16. Film marketed to amateurs, however, uses a restricted series including only powers of two multiples of ISO 100: 25, 50, 100, 200, 400, 800, 1600 and 3200. Some low-end cameras can only reliably read these values from [[DX encoding|DX encoded]] film cartridges because they lack the extra electrical contacts that would be needed to read the complete series. Some digital cameras extend this binary series to values like 12800, 25600, etc. instead of the modified Renard values 12500, 25000, etc.
The [[shutter speed]] controls how long the camera records light. These are expressed as fractions of a second, roughly but not exactly based on powers of 2: 1 second, {{frac|1|2}}, {{frac|1|4}}, {{frac|1|8}}, {{frac|1|15}}, {{frac|1|30}}, {{frac|1|60}}, {{frac|1|125}}, {{frac|1|250}}, {{frac|1|500}}, {{frac|1|1000}} of a second.
5:4, 8:5, 16:9.
==Retail packaging== In some countries, consumer-protection laws restrict the number of different prepackaged sizes in which certain products can be sold, in order to make it easier for consumers to compare prices.
An example of such a regulation is the European Union directive on the volume of certain prepackaged liquids (75/106/EEC<ref name="EEC_106"/>). It restricts the list of allowed wine-bottle sizes to 0.1, 0.25 ({{frac|1|4}}), 0.375 ({{frac|3|8}}), 0.5 ({{frac|1|2}}), 0.75 ({{frac|3|4}}), 1, 1.5, 2, 3, and 5 litres. Similar lists exist for several other types of products. They vary and often deviate significantly from any geometric series in order to accommodate traditional sizes when feasible. Adjacent package sizes in these lists differ typically by factors {{frac|2|3}} or {{frac|3|4}}, in some cases even {{frac|1|2}}, {{frac|4|5}}, or some other ratio of two small integers.

A '''quiver tip''' is a flexible extension to a [[fishing rod]] which is designed to move, or quiver, when a fish takes the bait. The main characteristic of its design is its sensitivity. It is a popular and very effective method of bite indication both on still and running water. It is not used in game fishing (i.e. salmon, trout and sea trout) and is seldom, if ever, used when fishing for very large coarse fish (e.g. carp or pike). In essence, the angler watches the tip of the fishing rod to detect bites as opposed to, say, a float or an electronic bite alarm.
==Description== The quiver tip is an extension of the fishing rod. The rod is specially designed to take quiver tips; nowadays, they are often called leger or feeder rods. Very sensitive float rods can be used for quiver tip fishing, but normally fishermen have a specialist rod especially for the task. The eyed tip of approximately 1–2 ft in length is attached as an extension to the end of the rod by a put-in or screw-in method. The quiver tip itself is a means of improving bite detection in conjunction with the ledgering method of fishing, whereby a [[weight]] is attached to the line close to the [[Fish hook|hook]] to assist in casting.
A variation of this method is the [[swim feeder]], which is a small weighted container with small holes in which loose [[eating|feed]] can be placed to attract [[fish]] to the area near the hook [[bait (luring substance)|bait]].
== Use == On still water fishing venues after casting, the rod should be placed in a rod rest at a 90 degree angle to the direction of the cast with the tip near to the water to reduce the effects of the wind vibration on the tip. On moving waters such as [[river]]s the rod should be placed on a stand pointing towards the direction of the [[Casting (fishing)|cast]] with the tip high in the air in order to reduce the impact of the water flow on the line. The line between the end of the tip and the weight/swim feeder should be [[tension (mechanics)|tension]]ed so that a slight bend in the quiver tip exists.
The reason for this is to allow for the detection of two types of bite.
The first type of bite occurs when the fish takes the [[Fishing bait|bait]] and moves away from the [[fisherman]], causing the line to tighten and pull on the quiver tip. The second type of bite occurs when the fish takes the bait and moves towards the fisherman causing the line to slacken and the quiver tip to drop back/straighten.
==Types== Quiver tips are, relative to the rods which hold them, inexpensive and found in all coarse fishing tackle shops. They can be bought in various test curves, which correspond to how stiff the tip is (often measured in [[ounce]]s.) The lower the test curve, the less stiff the tip is (i.e. the less weight required to bend the tip.) The test curve of the tip should be carefully considered as it could drastically impact on the bite detection/playing of the fish and should relate to the type of fish targeted and [[weather]] conditions.
As a general rule, it is desirable to fish with the lightest tip possible; that means the tip with the lightest test curve. This is because the lighter and more flexible the tip, the more sensitive and accurate the bite detection it provides.
One of the basic skills in quiver tip fishing is selecting the correct weight of the tip to match the target fish, having regard to the type of water and the prevailing weather conditions. For example, if British roach are being targeted on a stillwater in flat calm conditions, a quiver tip of a test curve of no more than an ounce would be a good choice. Alternatively, fishing for a strong aggressive fish like the British barbel in a fast-flowing river would require a heavier tip, possibly of three ounces or more - a lighter tip would be permanently bent round by the flow of the water, eliminating bite detection, and playing a strong fish would probably break it completely.
