'''1941 [[Solid body guitar|Electric guitar (solid body)]]''' * A solid body electric guitar, made up of hardwood with a lacquer coating, is an [[electric guitar]] that has no hollow internal cavity to accommodate vibration. There are no sound holes such as those used to amplify string vibrations in acoustic guitars. The sound that is audible in music featuring electric guitars is produced by pickups on the guitar that convert the string vibrations into an electrical signal, usually fed into an [[amplifier]] or a [[Computer speaker|speaker]]. The solid body guitar was invented in 1941 by American recording artist [[Les Paul]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Les Paul|publisher=Invent Now|url=http://www.invent.org/hall_of_fame/225.html|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110610005558/http://www.invent.org/hall_of_fame/225.html|archivedate=2011-06-10|df=}}</ref>
'''1942 [[Bazooka]]''' [[File:Soldier with Bazooka M1.jpg|180px|left|thumb|A soldier holding an M1 bazooka]] A bazooka is a shoulder-fired, man-portable recoilless rocket anti-tank weapon that features a solid rocket motor for propulsion, allowing for [[high explosive]] (HE) and [[High explosive anti-tank warhead|high-explosive anti-tank (HEAT) warheads]] to be delivered against [[armored vehicles]], machine gun nests, and fortified bunkers at ranges beyond that of a standard thrown [[grenade]] or mine. The bazooka was co-invented in February 1942 by [[Edward Uhl]], then a lieutenant in the [[United States Army]], and Colonel Leslie Skinner.<ref>{{cite book|title=A history of innovation: U.S. Army adaptation in war and peace|publisher=Government Printing Office|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=42Mh23JI8dQC&pg=PA73}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Edward G. Uhl: co-inventor of the bazooka|publisher=The Times|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/comment/obituaries/article7132242.ece | location=London|date=May 21, 2010}}</ref>
'''1943 [[Magnetic proximity fuze]]'''
A magnetic proximity fuze is a type of [[proximity fuze]] that initiates a detonator in a piece of ordnance such as a land mine, naval mine, depth charge, or shell when the fuse's magnetic equilibrium is upset by a magnetic object such as a tank or a submarine. In 1943, Panayottis John Eliomarkakis of Philiadelphia filed U.S. patent #2,434,551 which was issued on January 13, 1948.<ref>{{cite web|title=Magnetic Fuze|publisher=United States Patent and Trademark Office|url=http://www.google.com/patents?id=bp9HAAAAEBAJ&printsec=abstract&zoom=4#v=onepage&q&f=false}}</ref>
'''1943 Modern Coal Burning Steam Locomotive'''
This invention was only primarily used with steam locomotives that had booster valves or superchargers to heat the fire even hotter to produce extra power. The coal used was semi-bituminous and bituminous coal only inside the steam locomotives. Sadly, this invention lasted until 1960 when Diesel's fully replaced American railroads.
'''1943 [[Slinky]]'''
A Slinky or "Lazy Spring" is a toy consisting of a helical spring that stretches and can bounce up and down. It can perform a number of tricks, including traveling down a flight of steps end-over-end as it stretches and re-forms itself with the aid of gravity and its own momentum. The Slinky was invented in 1943 by American engineer [[Richard T. James]] while working in his home laboratory to invent a set of springs that could be used to support sensitive instruments on board ships and stabilize them even in rough seas. When he once accidentally knocked one of his springs off a shelf, James saw that, rather than flopping in a heap onto the floor, the spring "stepped" in a series of arcs from the shelf, to a stack of books, to a tabletop, to the floor, where it re-coiled itself and stood upright. In 1945, the James first exhibited his new toy at the [[Gimbels]], a department store located in Philadelphia. He sold 400 Slinkys in 90 minutes which was the start of a sensation that continues to this day.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Slinky|publisher=Massachusetts Institute of Technology|url=http://web.mit.edu/invent/iow/slinky.html}}</ref>
''' 1945 [[Microwave oven]]''' [[File:Microwave.750pix.jpg|180px|left|thumb|A microwave oven with a turn table located inside]] A microwave oven cooks or heats food by dielectric heating. Cooking food with microwaves was discovered by [[Percy Spencer]] on October 8, 1945, while building magnetrons for radar sets at Raytheon. Spencer was working on an active radar set when he noticed a strange sensation, and saw that a peanut candy bar he had in his pocket started to melt. Although he was not the first to notice this phenomenon, as the holder of 120 patents, Spencer was no stranger to discovery and experiment, and realized what was happening. The radar had melted his candy bar with microwaves. The first food to be deliberately cooked with microwaves was popcorn, and the second was an egg.<ref>{{cite web|title=Who Invented Microwaves?|publisher= J. Carlton Gallawa|url=http://www.gallawa.com/microtech/history.html}}</ref> In 1947, Raytheon under Percy Spencer demonstrated the world's first microwave oven built at the company which was called the "Radarange".<ref>{{cite web|title=Technology Leadership |publisher=Raytheon |url=http://www.raytheon.com/ourcompany/history/leadership/ |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130322044917/http://www.raytheon.com/ourcompany/history/leadership/ |archivedate=March 22, 2013 }}</ref>
'''1945 [[Cruise control]]'''
Cruise control automatically controls the rate of motion of a motor vehicle. The driver sets the speed and the system will take over the throttle of the car to maintain the same speed. Cruise control was invented in 1945 by a blind inventor and mechanical engineer named [[Ralph Teetor]]. His idea was born out of the frustration of riding in a car driven by his lawyer, who kept speeding up and slowing down as he talked. The first car with Teetor's system was the Chrysler Imperial in 1958. This system calculated ground speed based on driveshaft rotations and used a solenoid to vary throttle position as needed.<ref>{{cite web|title=Ralph Teetor: Inventor of Cruise Control|publisher=Dennis Horvath|url=http://www.cruise-in.com/resource/cismar08.htm|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20051104031820/http://www.cruise-in.com/resource/cismar08.htm|archivedate=2005-11-04|df=}}</ref>
'''1945 [[Block heater]]''' * A block heater warms the engine of an [[automobile]] in order to ease and speed starting and vehicle warm-up in cold weather. The most common type is an electric heating element connected through a [[power cord]] often routed through the vehicle's [[grille]]. The block heater may replace one of the engine's [[core plug]]s, or may be installed in line with one of the [[radiator]] or heater hoses. The block heater, first known as a head bolt heater, was invented in 1945 by [[Andrew Freeman (inventor)|Andrew Freeman]] in Grand Forks, North Dakota. Freeman used some scrap hoses and copper tubing onto the heating element of an old flat-iron and produced the first headbolt heater, which warmed the engine's water jacket and the oil film between cylinder heads and pistons.<ref>{{cite web|title=Your car starts? Thank Andrew Freeman|publisher=Minn Post|url=http://www.minnpost.com/chuckhaga/2008/02/07/815/your_car_starts_thank_andrew_freeman}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|title=Encyclopedia of the Great Plains|publisher=University of Nebraska Press|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rtRFyFO4hpEC&pg=PA421}}</ref> U.S. patent #2,487,326 was filed on November 4, 1946 and issued to Freeman on November 8, 1949.<ref>{{cite web|title=ELECTRIC INTERNAL-COMBUSTION ENGINE|publisher=United States Patent and Trademark Office|url=http://www.google.com/patents?id=a39XAAAAEBAJ&printsec=abstract#v=onepage&q&f=false}}</ref>

'''Unifly''' is a European [[software]] company that provides a platform for drone [[telematics]] services for [[unmanned]] [[traffic management]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.thedrive.com/tech/23247/unifly-to-provide-unmanned-traffic-management-system-for-new-york-drone-testing-corridor|title=Unifly to Provide UTM System for New York Drone Corridor|last=Margaritoff|first=Marco|work=The Drive|access-date=2018-09-26|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://dronelife.com/2018/07/21/unifly-aeronyde-to-create-drone-traffic-system-for-emergency-services/|title=Unifly, Aeronyde to Create Drone Traffic System for Emergency Services - DRONELIFE|website=dronelife.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-09-26}}</ref> The company provides mapping and location data to connect authorities with pilots for the safe integration of [[Unmanned aerial vehicle|drones]] into the airspace and unmanned aviation.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.suasnews.com/2017/03/dfs-unifly-cooperate-development-drone-app/|title=DFS and Unifly cooperate on the development of drone app - sUAS News - The Business of Drones|date=2017-03-10|work=sUAS News - The Business of Drones|access-date=2018-09-26|language=en-GB}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://techcrunch.com/2018/09/16/african-experiments-with-drone-technologies-could-leapfrog-decades-of-infrastructure-neglect/|title=African experiments with drone technologies could leapfrog decades of infrastructure neglect|work=TechCrunch|access-date=2018-09-26|language=en-US}}</ref> The company was a wholly owned subsidiary of [[VITO]] until a corporate spin-off in 2015. Unifly is headquartered in [[Antwerp, Belgium]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.eu-startups.com/2017/01/7-belgian-startups-to-look-out-for-in-2017/|title=7 Belgian startups to look out for in 2017 {{!}} EU-Startups|last=Ohr|first=Thomas|website=www.eu-startups.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-09-26}}</ref>
==History== Unifly was founded in 2015 by aerospace experts Andres Van Swalm, Jurgen Verstaen, Koen Meuleman and Hans Schrauwen..<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.geospatialworld.net/article/unifly-shaping-drone-space-with-luciad/|title=Unifly shaping drone space with Luciad's innovative platform|date=2017-11-30|work=Geospatial World|access-date=2018-09-26|language=en-US}}</ref> They worked on creating a platform to facilitate unmanned traffic management solutions in the aerospace for drones.<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=https://www.suasnews.com/2018/06/huawei-and-unifly-collaborate-to-identify-and-track-drone-flights/|title=Huawei and Unifly Collaborate to Identify and Track Drone Flights - sUAS News - The Business of Drones|date=2018-06-11|work=sUAS News - The Business of Drones|access-date=2018-09-26|language=en-GB}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.vision-systems.com/articles/2018/09/unmanned-systems-underwater-robot-reef-protector-u-s-navy-s-carrier-based-uas-unmanned-traffic-management.html|title=Unmanned systems: Underwater robot reef protector, U.S. Navy’s carrier-based UAS, unmanned traffic management|website=www.vision-systems.com|access-date=2018-09-26}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://uavs.insct.org/unifly-to-provide-unmanned-traffic-management-system-for-new-york-drone-testing-corridor/|title=Unifly to Provide Unmanned Traffic Management System for New York Drone Testing Corridor - Domesticating the Drone|date=2018-08-30|work=Domesticating the Drone|access-date=2018-09-26|language=en-US}}</ref> The company received $1.2 million in seed funding from PMV and Qbic Fund.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.cbinsights.com/company/unifly-funding|title=Unifly Funding & Investors - CB Insights|access-date=2018-09-26|language=en-US}}</ref> Again in 2016, it raised another round of series A funding of $5 million from Terra Drone for the business expansion and development.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.eu-startups.com/2016/11/antwerp-based-unifly-raises-e5-million-to-become-a-global-leader-with-its-drone-traffic-management-software/|title=Antwerp-based Unifly raises €5 million to become a global leader with its drone traffic management software {{!}} EU-Startups|last=Ohr|first=Thomas|website=www.eu-startups.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-09-26}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://tech.eu/brief/unifly-funding/|title=Drone traffic management software maker Unifly raises €5 million|work=Tech.eu|access-date=2018-09-26|language=en-US}}</ref>
In May 2018, Unifly announced that it has partnered with [[UNICEF]] to create a UTM drone corridor in [[Africa]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://dronelife.com/2018/05/10/unifly-unicef-develop-growing-utm-drone-corridor-in-malawi/|title=Unifly, UNICEF Develop Growing UTM Drone Corridor in Malawi - DRONELIFE|website=dronelife.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-09-26}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://unicefmalawi.wordpress.com/2018/06/14/how-the-first-unmanned-traffic-management-system-in-africa-is-supporting-humanitarian-drones-in-malawi/|title=Africa’s first UTM system is supporting humanitarian drones|date=2018-06-14|work=UNICEF Malawi|access-date=2018-09-26|language=en-US}}</ref> Later in the year the company announced its partnership with the Northeast UAS Airspace Integration Research Alliance (NUAIR) program for New York’s UAS Test Site to test drone mission for the proposed corridor.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://unmanned-aerial.com/nuair-partners-with-unifly-for-enhanced-uas-testing-in-new-york|title=NUAIR Partners with Unifly for Advanced UAS Testing in New York - Unmanned Aerial|date=2018-08-29|work=Unmanned Aerial|access-date=2018-09-26|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cnybj.com/nuair-alliance-unifly-partnership/|title=NUAIR Alliance, European firm partner on drone-research work|website=www.cnybj.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-09-26}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.uticaod.com/news/20180828/nuair-griffiss-announce-partnership-with-unifly|title=NUAIR, Griffiss announce partnership with Unifly|last=Madison|first=Samantha|work=Uticaod|access-date=2018-09-26|language=en}}</ref> As of 2018, the company has operations in [[Spain]], [[France]], [[Belgium]], [[Denmark]], [[Germany]], [[the US]], [[Malawi]], [[China]] and [[Japan]].
==Partnerships== Unify partnered with [[Here (company)|HERE Technologies]] that specialises in [[digital mapping]] and location services to enable airspace maps for drones.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://globenewswire.com/news-release/2018/01/05/1284177/0/en/HERE-and-Unifly-to-map-the-airspace-for-drones.html|title=HERE and Unifly to map the airspace for drones|last=GmbH|first=Here Deutschland|work=GlobeNewswire News Room|access-date=2018-09-26|language=en-US}}</ref> In 2018, Unify signed a [[Memorandum of understanding|memorandum of understanding (MoU)]] with China’s [[Huawei Technologies]] to cooperate in the field of unmanned traffic management (UTM) systems.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://datanews.knack.be/ict/nieuws/unifly-en-huawei-gaan-samenwerken/article-normal-1159407.html|title=Unifly en Huawei gaan samenwerken|date=2018-06-11|access-date=2018-09-26}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.ainonline.com/aviation-news/business-aviation/2018-06-11/huawei-unifly-team-utm|title=Huawei, Unifly Team on UTM|work=Aviation International News|access-date=2018-09-26|language=en}}</ref><ref name=":0" /> In August 2018, Unify formed a partnership with Integra Aviation Academy,<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.livedronenews.com/news/94946/unifly-integra-team-up-to-develop-new-drone-utm|title=Unifly, Integra Team Up to Develop New Drone UTM|work=Drone News|access-date=2018-09-26}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://dronelife.com/2018/04/26/unifly-flies-high-with-three-advisory-board-drone-veterans/|title=Unifly Flies High with Three Advisory Board Drone Veterans - DRONELIFE|website=dronelife.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-09-26}}</ref> NUAIR and [[Griffiss International Airport]] to visualize and manage drone traffic in the low-altitude airspace.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://insideunmannedsystems.com/nuair-alliance-announces-utm-partnership-with-unifly/|title=NUAIR Alliance Announces UTM Partnership with Unifly - Inside Unmanned Systems|date=2018-08-28|work=Inside Unmanned Systems|access-date=2018-09-26|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.airport-technology.com/news/deals-swissport-international-mitre-unifly/|title=Deals this week: Swissport International, MITRE Corporation, Unifly|date=2018-09-07|work=Airport Technology|access-date=2018-09-26|language=en-GB}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.atc-network.com/atc-news/nuair-alliance-announces-partnership-with-unifly|title=NUAIR Alliance announces partnership with Unifly|last=Unifly|date=2018-08-31|work=ATC Network|access-date=2018-09-26|language=en}}</ref>
==Projects== The company works on European projects for [[Framework_Programmes_for_Research_and_Technological_Development#Horizon_2020|Horizon 2020]] including, CORUS,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://cordis.europa.eu/project/rcn/211096_en.html|title=Concept of Operations for EuRopean UTM Systems {{!}} Projects {{!}} H2020 {{!}} CORDIS {{!}} European Commission|work=CORDIS {{!}} European Commission|access-date=2018-09-26}}</ref> CLASS,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://cordis.europa.eu/project/rcn/210633_en.html|title=CLear Air Situation for uaS: Maturing ground based technologies for a real-time Unmanned Aerial System Traffic Management System (UTMS) to monitor and separate Unmanned Aerial System (UAS) traffic {{!}} Projects {{!}} H2020 {{!}} CORDIS {{!}} European Commission|work=CORDIS {{!}} European Commission|access-date=2018-09-26}}</ref> SECOPS<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://cordis.europa.eu/project/rcn/210103_en.html|title=An Integrated Security Concept for Drone Operations {{!}} Projects {{!}} H2020 {{!}} CORDIS {{!}} European Commission|work=CORDIS {{!}} European Commission|access-date=2018-09-26}}</ref> and PODIUM.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://cordis.europa.eu/project/rcn/213198_en.html|title=Proving Operations of Drones with Initial UTM Management {{!}} Projects {{!}} H2020 {{!}} CORDIS {{!}} European Commission|work=CORDIS {{!}} European Commission|access-date=2018-09-28}}</ref>
==Awards== *2018: Infosecurity Tech Startup of the Year *2017: [[Luciad]] Geospatial Excellence Awards: Best Aviation Application.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.luciad.com/news/luciad-announces-winners-of-geospatial-excellence-awards-at-2017-user-conference|title=Luciad Announces Winners of Geospatial Excellence Awards at 2017 User Conference|access-date=2018-09-28|language=en}}</ref> *2017: Tech Startup Day: Scale-up of the Year.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://startups.be/blog/post/winners-tech-startup-day-awards-announced|title=Small Teaser and UniFly are startup and scale-up of the year!|last=Tibau|first=Frederik|website=startups.be|access-date=2018-09-28}}</ref> *2017: EU Drone Awards: Best Emerging Drone Company.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.dronesmonthly.com/unifly-awarded-best-emerging-drone-company-at-eu-drone-awards/|title=Unifly Awarded Best Emerging Drone Company At EU Drone Awards|date=2017-01-30|work=Drones Monthly|access-date=2018-09-28|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://uasweekly.com/2017/01/27/best-emerging-drone-company-award-won-unifly/|title=Best Emerging Drone Company’ Award Won by Unifly - UASweekly.com|date=2017-01-27|work=UASweekly.com|access-date=2018-09-28|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.siliconluxembourg.lu/unifly-wins-the-best-emerging-drone-company-award-at-eu-drone-awards/|title=Unifly Wins The Best Emerging Drone Company Award|date=2017-01-30|work=Silicon Luxembourg|access-date=2018-09-28|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://younginnovator.eu/2017/01/the-most-innovative-european-drone-companies-get-awarded-at-the-european-parliament/|title=The most innovative European drone companies get awarded at the European Parliament|date=2017-01-26|work=EYIF|access-date=2018-09-28|language=en-US}}</ref> *2016: Nacht van de KMO / Night of the SME: Most Promising Company

revision.comment: Reverted [[WP:AGF|good faith]] edits by [[Special:Contributions/173.90.48.99|173.90.48.99]] ([[User talk:173.90.48.99|talk]]): Not a typo - an express warranty is a type of warranty, as is an implied one. ([[WP:TW|TW]])
revision.text:
{{Globalize/US|date=September 2010}} In [[contract]] law, a '''warranty''' has various meanings but generally means a guarantee or promise<ref>Hogg M. (2011). ''Promises and Contract Law: Comparative Perspectives'', [https://books.google.com/books?id=cNaneRZu-_sC&pg=PA49 p. 48]. Cambridge University Press.</ref> which provides [[wiktionary:assurance|assurance]] by one party to the other party that specific facts or conditions are true or will happen. This factual guarantee may be enforced regardless of materiality<ref name=West&Lewis2009/>which allows for a [[legal remedy]] if that promise is not true or followed.
Although a warranty is in its simplest form an element of a contract, some warranties run with a product so that a manufacturer makes the warranty to a consumer with which the manufacturer has no direct contractual relationship.
A warranty may be express or implied, depending on whether the warranty is explicitly provided (typically written) and the jurisdiction. Warranties may also state that a particular fact is true at one point in time or that the fact will continue into the future (a "continuing warranty).
== Sale of goods == Warranties provided in the sale of goods (tangible [[product (business)|product]]s) vary according to jurisdiction, but commonly new goods are sold with implied warranty that the goods are as advertised. Used products, however, may be sold "[[as is]]" with no warranties.
In the United States, various laws apply, including provisions in the [[Uniform Commercial Code]] which provide for implied warranties.<ref>[http://www.lexisnexis.com/lawschool/study/outlines/html/contracts/contracts14.htm Warranties in Sales of Goods]. LexisNexis Study Outlines.</ref> However, these implied warranties were often limited by [[disclaimer]]s. In 1975 the [[Magnuson–Moss Warranty Act]] was passed to strengthen warranties on consumer goods.<ref name=12Magnuson/> Among other things, under the law implied warranties cannot be disclaimed if an express warranty is offered, and attorney fees may be recovered.<ref name=12Magnuson>[http://www.jtexconsumerlaw.com/V11N3/JCCL_Magnuson.pdf 12 Reasons to Love the Magnuson-Moss Act]. ''Journal of Texas Consumer Law''. Reprinted with permission from the [[National Consumer Law Center]].</ref> In some states, statutory warranties are required on new home construction, and "[[lemon law]]s" apply to motor vehicles.
=== Implied warranty === {{Main article|Implied warranty}}
Implied warranties are unwritten promises that arise from the nature of the transaction, and the inherent understanding by the buyer, rather than from the express representations of the seller. In the United States, Article 2 of the [[Uniform Commercial Code]] (which has been adopted with variations in each [[U.S. state|state]]) provides that the following two warranties are implied unless they are explicitly disclaimed (such as an "[[as is]]" statement):
*The '''warranty of merchantability''' is implied unless expressly disclaimed by name, or the sale is identified with the phrase "[[as is]]" or "with all faults." To be "merchantable", the goods must reasonably conform to an ordinary buyer's expectations. For example, a fruit that looks and smells good but has hidden defects may violate the warranty if its quality does not meet the standards for such fruit "as passes ordinarily in the trade". In [[Massachusetts]] [[consumer protection]] law, it is illegal to disclaim this warranty on household goods sold to consumers. *The '''warranty of fitness for a particular purpose''' is implied unless disclaimed when a buyer relies upon the seller to select the goods to fit a specific request. For example, this warranty is violated when a buyer asks a mechanic to provide tires for use on snowy roads and receives tires that are unsafe to use in snow.
=== Defects In Materials and Workmanship. === The most common kind of warranty on goods is a warranty that the product is free from defects in materials and workmanship. This simply promises that the manufacturer properly constructed the product, out of proper materials. This implies that the product will perform as well as such products customarily do.
It is common for these to be limited warranties, limiting the time the buyer has to make a claim. For example, a typical 90-day warranty on a television gives the buyer 90 days from the date of purchase to claim that the television was improperly constructed. Should the television fail after 91 days of normal usage, which because televisions customarily last longer than 91 days means there was a defect in the materials or workmanship of the television, the buyer nonetheless may not collect on the warranty because it is too late to file a claim.
Time-limited warranties are often confused with performance warranties. A 90-day performance warranty would promise that the television would work for 90 days, which is fundamentally different from promising that it was delivered free of defects and limiting the time the buyer has to prove otherwise.. But because the usual evidence that a product was delivered defective is that it later breaks, the effect is very similar.
One situation in which the effect of a time-limited warranty is different from the effect of a performance warranty is where the time limit exceeds a normal lifetime of the product. If a coat is designed to last two years, but has a 10-year limited warranty against defects in materials and workmanship, a buyer who wears the coat for 3 years and then finds it worn out would not be able to collect on the warranty. But it is different from a 2-year warranty because if the buyer starts wearing the coat 5 years after buying it, and finds it wears out a year later, the buyer would have a warranty claim in Year 6. On the other hand, a 10-year performance warranty would promise that the coat would last 10 years.
=== Satisfaction guarantee === In the United States, the [[Magnuson–Moss Warranty Act]] of 1976 provides for enforcement of a satisfaction guarantee warranty. In these cases, the advertiser must refund the full purchase price regardless of the reason for dissatisfaction.<ref>Andreoni J. (2005). [http://econ.ucsd.edu/~jandreon/WorkingPapers/verify.pdf Trust, Reciprocity, and Contract Enforcement: Experiments on Satisfaction Guaranteed].</ref>
=== Lifetime warranty === A lifetime warranty is usually a warranty against defects in materials and workmanship that has no time limit to make a claim, rather than a warranty that the product will perform for the lifetime of the buyer.<ref>[http://www.warrantyweek.com/archive/ww20090813.html Lifetime Warranties]. ''Warranty Week''. [https://www.webcitation.org/6H0uHIxKE WebCite Archive].</ref> The actual time that product can be expected to perform is normally determined by the custom for products of its kind used the way the buyer uses it.
If a product has been discontinued and is no longer available, the warranty may last a limited period longer. For example:
* the Cisco Limited Lifetime Warranty currently lasts for five years after the product has been discontinued, but only if you know where you bought it from as the seller is responsible for administering it.<ref>{{Cite web | title = Cisco Limited Lifetime Hardware Warranty Terms| url=http://www.cisco.com/en/US/docs/general/warranty/English/LH2DEN__.html| accessdate = 2008-09-10 }}</ref> * HP Networking product lifetime warranties last for as long as one owns the product.<ref>{{Cite web| title = HP Networking warranty information| url=http://h17007.www1.hp.com/us/en/support/warranty/index.aspx| accessdate = 2011-08-26 }}</ref>
=== Breach of warranty === Warranties are violated when the promise is broken or the goods are not as expected. The seller may honor the warranty by making a refund or a replacement. The [[statute of limitations]] depends on the jurisdiction and contractual agreements. In the United States, the [[Uniform Commercial Code]] § 2-725 provides for a four-year time limit, which can be limited to one year by contract, starting from the date of delivery or if future performance is guaranteed from the date of discovery. Refusing to honor the warranty may be an [[unfair business practice]]. In the United States, breach of warranty lawsuits may be distinct from [[revocation]] of contract suits; in the case of the breach of warranty, the buyer's item is repaired or replaced while breach of contract involves returning the item to the seller.<ref>Davis T. (2009). [http://www.baylor.edu/content/services/document.php/116813.pdf UCC Breach of Warranty and Contract Claims: Clarifying the Distinction]. ''Baylor Law Review''.</ref>
Some warranties require that repairs be undertaken by an [[authorized service provider]]. In such cases, service by non-authorized personnel or company may [[void (law)|void]] (nullify) the warranty. However, according to the Magnuson-Moss Act (a U.S. Federal law that governs warranties, which was passed in 1975), if the warranty does not provide full or partial payment of labor (to repair the device or system), it is the owner's choice who will provide the labor, including the possibility of DIY ("Do It Yourself") repairs, in which case the device or system owner will pay zero dollars for labor, yet the company that provided the warranty must still provide all the parts needed for the repair at absolutely no charge to the owner.
If the defective product causes injury, this may be a [[cause of action]] for a [[product liability]] lawsuit ([[tort]]). [[Strict liability]] may be applied.
== Extended warranty == In addition to standard warranties on new items, third parties or manufacturers may sell extended warranties (also called service contracts).<ref>{{cite web|title=Appliances - 247 Home Rescue |url=https://www.247homerescue.co.uk/appliance-breakdown-cover/ |accessdate=26 June 2015 |publisher=247 Home Rescue}}</ref> These extend the warranty for a further length of time. However, these warranties have terms and conditions which may not match the original terms and conditions. For example, these may not cover anything other than mechanical failure from normal usage. Exclusions may include commercial use, "acts of God", owner abuse, and malicious destruction. They may also exclude parts that normally wear out such as tires and lubrication on a vehicle.
These types of warranties are provided for various products, but [[automobile]]s and [[Small appliance|electronics]] are common examples. Warranties which are sold through retailers such as [[Best Buy]] may include significant commission for the retailer as a result of [[reverse competition]].<ref>Baker T, Siegelman P. (2013). [http://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers.cfm?abstract_id=2199569 Protecting Consumers from Add-On Insurance Products: New Lessons for Insurance Regulation].</ref> For instance, an auto warranty from a [[car dealership]] may be subcontracted and vehicle repairs may be at a lower rate which could compromise the quality of service. At the time of repair, out-of-pocket expenses may be charged for unexpected services provided outside of the warranty terms or uncovered parts.
== Representations versus warranties == {{Further information|Misrepresentation}}
Statements of fact in a contract or in obtaining the contract are considered to be either warranties or representations. Traditionally, warranties are factual promises which are enforced through a contract legal action, regardless of materiality, intent, or reliance.<ref name=West&Lewis2009/> Representations are traditionally precontractual statements which allow for a tort-based action if the misrepresentation is negligent or fraudulent.<ref name=Primack2009>Primack MA. (2009). [http://www.natlawreview.com/article/representations-warranties-and-covenants-back-to-basics-contracts Representations, Warranties and Covenants: Back to the Basics in Contracts]. ''National Law Review''.</ref> In U.S. law, the distinction between the two is somewhat unclear;<ref name=West&Lewis2009/> warranties are viewed as primarily contract-based legal action while negligent or fraudulent misrepresentations are tort-based, but there is a confusing mix of case law in the United States.<ref name=West&Lewis2009>West GD, Lewis WB. (2009). [http://www.weil.com/files/Publication/563ccf98-648d-4e5b-b3e5-129805230615/Presentation/PublicationAttachment/fb77618a-f943-4797-98a1-2a69d92a4522/Extra-Contractual%20Liability%20Article.pdf Contracting to Avoid Extra-Contractual Liability—Can Your Contractual Deal Ever Really Be the "Entire" Deal?] ''The Business Lawyer''.</ref> In modern English law, sellers often avoid using the term 'represents' in order to avoid claims under the [[Misrepresentation Act 1967]], while in America 'warrants and represents' is relatively common.<ref name=JonesDay2007>Ferara LN, Philips J, Runnicles J. (2007). [http://www.jonesday.com/some-differences-in-law-and-practice-between-uk-and-us-stock-purchase-agreements-04-13-2007/ Some Differences in Law and Practice Between U.K. and U.S. Stock Purchase Agreements]. ''Jones Day Publications''.</ref> Some modern commentators suggest avoiding the words and substituting 'state' or 'agree', and some model forms do not use the words;<ref name=Primack2009/> however, others disagree.<ref>Telman J. (2012). [http://lawprofessors.typepad.com/contractsprof_blog/2012/05/representations-and-warranties.html Representations and Warranties]. ContractsProf Blog.</ref>
== Product types ==
=== Appliance warranty === <!-- linked from redirect [[Appliance warranty]] -->
====Canada and United States====
Written warranties on new major appliances, such as [[refrigerator]]s, [[kitchen stove]]s and [[dishwasher]]s, usually cover the cost of parts and labor to repair defects in materials or workmanship which appear under normal home use.
Warranties often cover defects up to a year after purchase or delivery.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.angieslist.com/articles/are-extended-warranties-appliances-worth-it.htm |title=Are Extended Warranties on Appliances Worth It? |last=Moor |first=Tom |year=2016 |publisher=Angies' List |publication-date=2016-07-22 | accessdate=16 January 2017|quote=Most manufacturers offer warranties for appliances that last from three months to up to one year.}}</ref> However some exclude new owners when a house or appliance is sold within the year ([[Frigidaire]],<ref name="frigidaire">{{cite web | url=http://manuals.frigidaire.com/prodinfo_pdf/Anderson/241979200en.pdf | title=Frigidaire, All about the Use & Care of your Refrigerator | publisher=Electrolux | accessdate=11 September 2016 | pages=20}}</ref> [[LG]],<ref name="lg">{{cite web | url=http://www.lg.com/us/support-product/lg-LFX31925ST | title=LG OWNER’S MANUAL FRENCH DOOR REFRIGERATOR | publisher=LG | accessdate=11 September 2016 | pages=55–58}}</ref> [[Samsung]]<ref name="whirlpool">{{cite web | url=http://www.whirlpool.com/digitalassets/ET0MSRXTL/Warranty_EN.pdf | title=WHIRLPOOL® REFRIGERATOR WARRANTY | publisher=Whirlpool | accessdate=11 September 2016}}</ref>). Others do let warranties transfer to new buyers ([[Amana Corporation|Amana]],<ref name="amana">{{cite web | url=http://www.amana.com/assets/amana/pdfs/WARRANTY/AMC5143AAW_Warranty.pdf | title=AMANA® MAJOR APPLIANCE WARRANTY | publisher=Amana | accessdate=11 September 2016}}</ref> [[General Electric]],<ref name="ge" /> [[Whirlpool]]). Some manufacturers cover refrigerators' sealed parts (compressors, tubing, etc.) for five years ([[General Electric]],<ref name="ge">{{cite web | url=http://products.geappliances.com/MarketingObjectRetrieval/Dispatcher?RequestType=PDF&Name=003671728.PDF | title=GE Appliances, Refrigerators, Owner's Manual | publisher=General Electric | accessdate=11 September 2016 | pages=11}}</ref> [[Samsung]],<ref name="samsung">{{cite web | url=http://www.samsung.com/in/support/html/warrantyinformation/warrantyinformation7.html | title=Refrigerator Product Info | publisher=Samsung | accessdate=11 September 2016}}</ref> [[Whirlpool]])<ref name="whirlpool" /> or seven years ([[LG]]<ref name="lg" />) or ten years ([[KitchenAid]]<ref name="kitchenaid">{{cite web | url=http://www.kitchenaid.com/digitalassets/MLPDF/Warranty%20Page%20-%202305802-W.pdf | title=KITCHENAID® REFRIGERATOR WARRANTY | publisher=KitchenAid | accessdate=23 September 2016}}</ref>).
Warranties on [[Water heating|water heaters]] cover parts for 5 to 12 years in single family residences, one year otherwise. They do not cover new owners when a house or heater is sold; nor do they cover the original owner if the heater is moved to a second location.<ref name="rheem">{{Cite web |url=http://cdn.globalimageserver.com/fetchDocument.aspx?id=95f29833-68e0-4e84-8f1a-3adea90df312 |title=Certificate of Limited Warranty, Rheem and Ruud Water Heaters |date=2014-09-01 |website=ruud.com/product/ruud-residential-electric-water-heaters-professional-achiever-series-standard-electric/#specs-docs |access-date=2017-10-13}}</ref> <ref name="ruud-tl">{{Cite web |url=http://cdn.globalimageserver.com/fetchDocument.aspx?id=ccbda862-a70e-47a8-b80c-18aa258b903f |title=Rheem Limited Warranty For the RHEEM®, RUUD®, Richmond®, Paloma®, and Sure Comfort® Residential Tankless Gas Water Heaters |website=ruud.com/product/ruud-condensing-tankless-professional-ultra-series-96-direct-vent-indoor/#specs-docs |access-date=2017-10-13}}</ref> <ref name="smith">{{Cite web |url=https://www.hotwater.com/lit/ws/res-elec/100293072.pdf |last=AO Smith ||title=Limited Warranty [nor manufactured housing]|date=2017-08-01 |website=hotwater.com/resources/product-literature/warranty-sheets/residential-electric/ |access-date=2017-10-13}}</ref> <ref name="smith-mh">{{Cite web |url=https://www.hotwater.com/lit/ws/res-elec/184866-001.pdf |title=AO Smith Water Heaters, Residential Electric Warranty [Manufactured Housing] |website=hotwater.com/resources/product-literature/warranty-sheets/residential-electric/ |access-date=2017-10-13}}</ref> <ref name="smith-tl">{{Cite web |url=https://www.hotwater.com/lit/ws/res-gas/OnDemand_Warranty.pdf |title=Warranty |last=A. O. Smith |website=hotwater.com/resources/product-literature/warranty-sheets/tankless/ |access-date=2017-10-13}}</ref> Tank models from [[A. O. Smith]] do not allow heating elements to be replaced with lower (or higher) wattages, and do not cover renter-occupied single family. They end if the unit is flooded or ever uses [[Desalination|desalinated]] or [[Purified_water#Deionization|deionized]] water, such as [[Desalination_facilities#United_States|municipal desalination]] plants or [[reverse osmosis]] filters.<ref name="smith"></ref><ref name="smith-mh"></ref> Smith's tank models for [[manufactured housing]] do not provide coverage if a whirlpool or hot tub is connected.<ref name="smith-mh"></ref>
Tank water heater warranties exclude labor, liability for water damage, and shipping cost to return the old heater or parts. Tankless warranties do not exclude water damage; they cover labor for a year, and Ruud/Rheem covers return shipping on tankless models.<ref name="ruud-tl"></ref><ref name="smith-tl"></ref> Smith's tankless water heaters do not restrict coverage to a single family, and require professional installation.<ref name="smith-tl"></ref>
Implied warranties under US law could extend for longer periods. However, most states allow the written warranties to include clauses which limit these implied warranties to the same time period as the written warranty.<ref name="cr">{{cite web | url=http://www.consumerreports.org/cro/magazine/2013/05/the-word-on-warranty-protection/index.htm | title=What you need to know about warranty laws | publisher=Consumer Reports | date=2013 | accessdate=11 September 2016}}</ref>
=== Car warranty ===
====United States====
New car factory warranties commonly range from one year to five years and in some cases extend even 10 years, with typically a mileage limit as well. Car warranties can be extended by the manufacturer or other companies with a renewal fee.
Used car warranties are usually 3 months and 3,000 miles
====United Kingdom====
In the United Kingdom, types of warranties have been classified as either an: # original manufacturer warranty, # insurance warranty underwritten and regulated as insurance or # obligor warranty, typically written by a car dealership or garage.
In the United Kingdom, the [[Financial Conduct Authority]] (FCA), which began to regulate insurance contracts in this context in 2005, determined that additional warranties sold by car dealerships are "unlikely to be insurance".<ref>[http://www.fsa.gov.uk/smallfirms/resources/factsheets/pdfs/factsheet10.pdf What is a contract of insurance?]. Financial Services Authority.</ref> Insurance warranties may offer greater protection to the consumer.
=== Home Warranty === {{Main article|Home warranty}}
A home warranty protects against the costs of home and appliance repair by offering home warranty coverage for houses, townhomes, condominiums, mobile homes, and new construction homes. When a problem occurs with a covered appliance or mechanical system such as an air conditioning unit or furnace, a service technician repairs or replaces it. The homeowner may have to pay for a service call fee and the home warranty company pays the balance for the repair or replacement of the covered item.
==Warranty data== Warranty data consists of claims data and supplementary data. Claims data are the data collected during the servicing of claims under warranty and supplementary data are additional data such as production and marketing data.<ref name=Wu>Wu S. (2012). [https://dx.doi.org/10.1002/qre.1282 Warranty Data Analysis: A Review]. ''[[Quality and Reliability Engineering International]]''.</ref> This data can help determine product reliability and plan for future modifications.<ref name=Wu/>

'''Wet-milling''' is a process in which [[feedstock|feed material]] is [[steeped]] in water, with or without [[sulfur dioxide]], to soften the seed [[Corn kernel|kernel]] in order to help separate the kernel’s various components. For example, wet-milling plants can separate a 56-pound bushel of corn into more than 31 pounds of [[cornstarch]] (which in turn can be converted into [[corn syrup]]s or [[corn ethanol]]), 15 pounds of [[corn gluten meal]] for use in [[compound feed|animal feed]], and nearly 2 pounds of [[corn oil]].
==See also== *[[Corn steep liquor]] *[[Corn wet-milling]]

{{Infobox company | name = ZeoBIT LLC | logo = | type = [[Private Company]] | industry = [[Security software]]
[[Computer software]] | foundation = [[United States]] ({{Start date|2009|9|}}) | founder = Slava Kolomiychuk | location_city = Sunnyvale, California | location_country = United States | area_served = United States | products = [[MacKeeper]], [[PCKeeper]] | website = [https://web.archive.org/web/20120604200326/http://zeobit.com/ zeobit.com (archived)] }} Zeobit LLC (stylized ZeoBIT) was a technology and [[software]] company formed in 2009 by CEO Slava Kolomiychuk and located in [[Sunnyvale, California]]. The company specialized in computer security software and internet security. As of December 2016, it is no longer in business.[https://www.bbb.org/losangelessiliconvalley/business-reviews/computer-software-publishers-and-developers/zeobit-in-sunnyvale-ca-1000004640#reasonrating ZeoBIT, LLC Business Review in Sunnyvale, California] Zeobit is best known for the bundled utility software [[MacKeeper]]. The software has received mixed reviews with reviewers being very divided as to the effectiveness of the product. == History == Zeobit LLC was incorporated in September 2009 in the US State of [[California]] by Slava Kolomiychuk. Zeobit has a management headquarters in [[Sunnyvale, California]] and partnership offices in [[Europe]] and [[Asia]] that house developers and the customer support. In March 2010 their first product, [[MacKeeper]] (for [[macOS]]) was released and in September 2010 PCKeeper (for [[Microsoft Windows]]) was released. On May 13, 2010, the first beta version of MacKeeper, version 0.8, was released. On October 4, 2010, PCKeeper (MacKeeper's equivalent for Windows PCs) (version 1.1.48) was released. On October 26, 2010, Zeobit released MacKeeper 1.0. On January 30, 2012, MacKeeper 2.0 was released with updates in security, data control, cleaning and optimization. In 2014, a Pennsylvania woman filed a class action lawsuit against Zeobit LLC, claiming that the company's computer security program identifies problems that don't exist and generates false error messages to scare users into purchasing an upgrade. (see Holly Yencha, et al. v. Zeobit LLC, Case No. 2:13-cv-00578, in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Pennsylvania.) According to the complaint filed in US District court, "Once installed, MacKeeper prompts the user to conduct a diagnostic scan", the MacKeeper class action lawsuit says. "This scan purportedly detects errors that lead to the problems identified in Zeobit's marketing materials (i.e., performance issues, security and privacy threats)—problems that MacKeeper is supposedly designed to fix." However, the Zeobit class action lawsuit alleges that after the diagnostic scan is completed, MacKeeper reports that it identified thousands of issues that cause the computer to be in "critical" condition. While the trial version of MacKeeper purports to "fix" a limited number of the issues, customers are encouraged to purchase a full, registered version of the security software to fully repair the computer. Yencha alleges that neither the free trial nor the full versions of MacKeeper perform reliable diagnostic testing of the computer. "Instead, Zeobit intentionally designed MacKeeper to invariably and ominously report that a user's Mac needs repair and is at-risk due to harmful (but fabricated) errors, privacy threats, and other computer problems, regardless of the computer's actual condition", the class action lawsuit alleges. The Class Action was settled in 2015 with no admission of wrongdoing and customers were given refunds. == Products == === MacKeeper === {{main article|MacKeeper}} [[MacKeeper]] is utility software for macOS that claims to provide tools for security, cleaning, optimization and data control. MacKeeper and Zeobit were the official sponsors of the MacWorld / iWorld expo in San Francisco, California in 2011 & 2012.[http://www.macworldiworld.com/sponsors ZeoBIT is MacWorld sponsor] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120630063114/http://www.macworldiworld.com/sponsors |date=June 30, 2012 }} It was acquired by Kromtech Alliance Corp in May 2013. MacKeeper is often criticized for unethical marketing tactics, including [[pop-up advertising]] and buying domain names similar to the names of other antivirus programs.{{cite web|last1=Reed|first1=Thomas|title=Ongoing MacKeeper Fraud|url=http://www.thesafemac.com/ongoing-mackeeper-fraud/|website=The Safe Mac|publisher=Malwarebytes|accessdate=28 August 2017}} Zeobit claims their affiliates were responsible for the advertising accused as unethical. MacKeeper is sometimes referred to as a [[potentially unwanted program]] and is detected by some antivirus programs.{{cite web|last1=Reed|first1=Thomas|title=PUP Friday: MacKeeper|url=https://blog.malwarebytes.com/puppum/2016/08/pup-friday-mackeeper/|website=Malwarebytes Labs|publisher=Malwarebytes|accessdate=28 August 2017}} === PCKeeper === PCKeeper is a bundle of most important system utilities for performing different tasks on the PС, such as antivirus, data control and optimization tools, drive clean-up utilities and much more. According to [[Virus Bulletin]], PCKeeper has scored 91.9% in RAP test and was listed as number 6 antivirus in the world.[http://www.virusbtn.com/vb100/archive/test?id=74 Virus Bulletin] It was acquired by Kromtech Alliance Corp in May 2013. === ZeoDisk === The ZeoDisk project is a cloud storage solution that will also be integrated in to the existing Zeobit products.{{cn|date=August 2017}} == Partnerships == In 2011 Zeobit partnered with [[Avira]] to integrate their virus database technology in [[Mackeeper|MacKeeper]] and PCKeeper’s [[Internet Security]] features. This partnership allowed Zeobit to offer internet security options for the [[macOS]], [[Windows]], [[Linux]], [[FreeBSD]], [[OpenBSD]], and [[Solaris (operating system)|Solaris]] computing platforms. Zeobit was a member of the [[Better Business Bureau]]. It had an F rating, due to complaints about its advertising and the quality of its products.[https://www.bbb.org/losangelessiliconvalley/business-reviews/computer-software-publishers-and-developers/zeobit-in-sunnyvale-ca-1000004640#reasonrating ZeoBIT, LLC Business Review in Sunnyvale, California] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160807151725/https://www.bbb.org/losangelessiliconvalley/business-reviews/computer-software-publishers-and-developers/zeobit-in-sunnyvale-ca-1000004640#reasonrating}} Zeobit was a [[Microsoft]] Silver Certified developer.[http://pinpoint.microsoft.com/en-US/PartnerDetails.aspx?PartnerId=4298097895 ZeoBIT LLC - Microsoft Pinpoint] Zeobit was an official [[OPSWAT]] partner.[http://www.opswat.com/certified/opswat-certified-partners opswat.com] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120915145854/http://www.opswat.com/certified/opswat-certified-partners |date=September 15, 2012 }} ==References== {{Reflist}} == External links == *[https://web.archive.org/web/20120604200326/http://zeobit.com/ Zeobit website (archived)] *[http://mackeeper.zeobit.com/ MacKeeper website] *[http://pckeeper.zeobit.com/ PCKeeper website] [[Category:Computer companies of the United States]] [[Category:Electronics companies]] [[Category:Software companies based in California]] [[Category:Technology companies of the United States]] [[Category:Computer security software companies]] [[Category:Companies based in Sunnyvale, California]]
